Title: Library of Congress/Coordinator of Information/Office of Strategic Services
Ancestor Notes: Folders in Series 2 document Burton’s varied career as an academic, a diplomat, and a foundation officer.  There is minimal documentation for his tenure at Pomona College, the Office of Strategic Services and later Department of State, Muhlenberg College, and Grolier, Inc.  More detailed information exists for his five years at Miami University, and extensive documentation is included for his career at the Rockefeller Foundation and the Embassy of the United States in Tokyo, Japan.    The Rockefeller Foundation diaries are an incomplete set and are draft versions of the final diaries filed with the Rockefeller Foundation and found in their archives.  The drafts do not appear to differ significantly from the final versions.  Of interest in this series is Fahs’s report to John Marshall chronicling his train trip from Paris to Kyoto in 1934 (Box 6, Folder 85).  The many reports and memoranda written by Fahs while at the Rockefeller Foundation and at Miami University offer his opinions on education, international study, and cultural exchange and evaluations of proposed changes to study abroad programs and support of universities in developing nations.  The invitations and related materials from his time at the Embassy in Japan are also important items from his diplomatic career.  Researchers interested in the early career of Charles Burton Fahs should also explore the correspondence files in Series 1 dated from this period; during his early career, there was an overlap between Fahs’s personal and professional life.  Series 4, Manuscripts, Publications, and Speeches contains the many articles and book reviews written by Fahs during his time at Pomona College, as well as other articles and speeches made throughout his career.

Title: Massachusetts Department of Mental Diseases
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Yale University - Institute of Human Relations
Ancestor Notes: This series includes material for grants given to organizations that are national in scope but that fall outside the Foundation's established program divisions. Files are organized alphabetically. This series includes documentation of grants given as the result of the founder's designation and grants to such institutions as the American Baptist Home Mission Society, the American Council on Education, Biological Abstracts, a bird refuge in Louisiana, the Bureau of Municipal Research, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, the National Research Council, and prominent universities such as Johns Hopkins, Harvard and Yale. Also included in this series are files on the Foundation's support of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced Foreign Scholars and its support for Refugee Scholars during the 1930s and 1940s.

Title: University of Toronto - Child Study
Ancestor Notes: The first Foundation grant to Canada was as part of a relief effort in Newfoundland (1914). As part of regular program oriented support, the Foundation supported various medical and public health projects, especially between 1920 and 1950. Dalhousie and McGill University, the Universities of Manitoba and Montreal, and various Provincial governments were the main beneficiaries of the Foundation's interests in these areas.   In the humanities, the Foundation gave grants for folklore studies, library surveys, and drama, mainly in the 1940's. Support for the social sciences came mainly through grants and fellowships administered by the Canadian social Science Research Council (1940-1957) and various universities.

Title: Cornell University - Civil Liberties
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry - Andrews, Donald
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Society for a More Beautiful National Capital
Ancestor Notes: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.  Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.  The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.   A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.  The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

Title: Leger, Alexis (Saint-John Perse)
Component Notes: John Marshall campaigned with others for author to receive Nobel Prize (1960).   | See also Rockefeller Foundation Archives, Record Group 1.1, Series 200R, Box 241, Folders 2877-2878 (RF Refugee Scholar in French Literature).
Ancestor Notes: This series includes material relating directly to Rockefeller Foundation activities and to John Marshall's professional work.  The files of speeches, articles, and thought pieces in Series 1 cover a range of topics and reflect Mr. Marshall's thoughts on the humanities program, 1933-1970. Most, but not all, were authorized by Mr. Marshall.  Of special interest are the David H. Stevens file, which includes notes on his tenure at the Rockefeller Foundation and on Rockefeller Foundation Humanities personnel, 1929-1950, and the folder of General Education Board material, which deals with a review of interpretation at Colonial Williamsburg in 1939.

Title: Commission for the Prevention of Tuberculosis in France - Volume XI - Publicity Material
Ancestor Notes: Grants to French institutions were made primarily in the medical sciences field. The earliest grants were awarded for the campaign against tuberculosis, from which the Foundation's nursing program was created. The University of Paris was the major recipient of grants for the medical sciences. Funds were given for work by Th. Alajouanine, Jean Scherrer, and Clovis Vincent in neurology and neurosurgery and by Georges Heuyer in psychiatry. Funding was given to the Radium Institute in the 1920's, 1930's, and 1940's. The University of Lyons and the University of Strasbourg were also recipients of a relatively large number of medical sciences grants. In addition, there are files dealing with the Pearce report on French medical education which was part of a report on medical education throughout the world.   The Rockefeller Foundation also gave funding to a full range of humanities and social sciences programs. A large number of grants were given for work in philosophy. Grants were also given for a broad range of studies including art history and geography and ethnology. A number of humanities and social sciences grants were made to refugee scholars, including Richard Alewyn (German Literature), Elias Bickermann (Greek archeology), Kurt Sachs (music history), Julius Lewy (Assyriology), and Paul Schrecker (Philosophy).   The American Library in Paris and the Bibliotheque Nationale also received Foundation support.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biological Research
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Report Drafts - Heilbroner, Robert - Comments by Kissinger, Free, Cantril
Ancestor: Subpanel VII: The Moral Framework of National Purpose (series)
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, papers, drafts, and final reports. Organization files, which are brief, concern the planning of subpanel activities. Membership files, as well as the correspondence that accompanies files in the Papers section, document discussions and writing on issues considered by the subpanel. The Papers files provide comprehensive presentations of the views of various subpanel experts on selected topics. Meeting files contain summaries and sometimes minute of subpanel discussions of issues. The Reports files, containing several drafts of each report, show the progressive synthesizing of the views of a subpanel's members.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy - Report
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Refugee Scholars - Report - Appleget, Thomas B. - "Refugee Scholars Program, 1940" RF DR 555 - Ref-2
Ancestor Notes: This series includes material for grants given to organizations that are national in scope but that fall outside the Foundation's established program divisions. Files are organized alphabetically. This series includes documentation of grants given as the result of the founder's designation and grants to such institutions as the American Baptist Home Mission Society, the American Council on Education, Biological Abstracts, a bird refuge in Louisiana, the Bureau of Municipal Research, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, the National Research Council, and prominent universities such as Johns Hopkins, Harvard and Yale. Also included in this series are files on the Foundation's support of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced Foreign Scholars and its support for Refugee Scholars during the 1930s and 1940s.

Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Graduate Faculty of Political & Social Science - Ascoli, Max - (Refugee Scholar, Political Science)
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Rockefeller Foundation - General Education Board Fellowship
Ancestor Notes: Folders in Series 2 document Burton’s varied career as an academic, a diplomat, and a foundation officer.  There is minimal documentation for his tenure at Pomona College, the Office of Strategic Services and later Department of State, Muhlenberg College, and Grolier, Inc.  More detailed information exists for his five years at Miami University, and extensive documentation is included for his career at the Rockefeller Foundation and the Embassy of the United States in Tokyo, Japan.    The Rockefeller Foundation diaries are an incomplete set and are draft versions of the final diaries filed with the Rockefeller Foundation and found in their archives.  The drafts do not appear to differ significantly from the final versions.  Of interest in this series is Fahs’s report to John Marshall chronicling his train trip from Paris to Kyoto in 1934 (Box 6, Folder 85).  The many reports and memoranda written by Fahs while at the Rockefeller Foundation and at Miami University offer his opinions on education, international study, and cultural exchange and evaluations of proposed changes to study abroad programs and support of universities in developing nations.  The invitations and related materials from his time at the Embassy in Japan are also important items from his diplomatic career.  Researchers interested in the early career of Charles Burton Fahs should also explore the correspondence files in Series 1 dated from this period; during his early career, there was an overlap between Fahs’s personal and professional life.  Series 4, Manuscripts, Publications, and Speeches contains the many articles and book reviews written by Fahs during his time at Pomona College, as well as other articles and speeches made throughout his career.
Resource Access Restriction: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Title: Japan - McLean (Donald H.) Reports
Ancestor Notes: Through correspondence, reports, and memoranda, this subseries documents Rockefeller's interest in and commitment to Asia. Rockefeller was deeply concerned about the need for increasing America's understanding and appreciation of the peoples of Asia. To that end, he was involved in the support of cultural exchange programs; the revival of the Japan Society; the formation of the Asia Society; the construction of Asia House, the Asia Society's New York City headquarters; and the construction of the International House of Japan in Tokyo. The files documenting the teaching of the English language in Japan (folders 452-455) reflect Rockefeller's belief in the importance of English to Japan's growth in the international community. Also included here are files relating to the Council on Economic and Cultural Affairs, Inc. (CECA), an organization established by Rockefeller in 1953 to stimulate and support economic and related activities focusing on Asia. Rockefeller's work for the John Foster Dulles peace mission to Japan in 1951 led to a renewed acquaintance with Shigeharu Matsumoto, with whom he had worked at the Institute of Pacific Relations conference in 1929. The Matsumoto and Rockefeller families became close friends. Included in this subseries are Rockefeller's report for Dulles and the State Department (folder 446), as well as correspondence between Matsumoto and JDR 3rd (folders 477-478). Also represented here are two commercial ventures developed by Rockefeller to sell in the United States quality merchandise manufactured in Asia, namely, Products of Asia, Inc. and Products of India, Inc. These companies, which were meant to increase trade and encourage cultural contact, were sold in 1965. | For additional Matsumoto family correspondence see series 3, subseries 2, folder 147.

Title: Biography - "A Conversation with Charles Burton Fahs" and Chronology
Ancestor Notes: This series consists of family materials and correspondence, as well as several versions of a biography of Charles Burton Fahs compiled and written by Jamie Ross Fahs.  This series also contains information on Burton’s education, and his illness and death.  There are files of correspondence and clippings which post-date Burton’s death; these materials were received and collected by Jamie Ross Fahs and were included in the collection because of their connection to Burton’s life and career.  The correspondence folders are extremely rich and detailed and provide a window into the lives and activities of Burton and Jamie throughout their lives.  Folders which begin with the word Correspondence indicate that the letters in the file are written by Burton.  Incoming correspondence is rare, and there are no letters between the spouses.    Correspondence from Burton’s childhood includes letters written or received by his parents, as well as maternal aunt Abbie Lyon Sharman, her husband Harry Sharman, and maternal uncle D. Willard Lyon and his wife Grace.  Burton was a regular correspondent with his family during his college and graduate school years.  After they were married, Burton and Jamie took turns writing to his family.  There are also a few letters to Jamie’s mother.  Both Burton and Jamie were faithful correspondents, writing every one to two weeks.  The letters dating from 1933-1936, when they lived abroad, are particularly fascinating for the details they offer of living conditions and adjustments to cultural differences.  During Burton’s career at the Embassy, Jamie served as the family’s main correspondent and wrote lengthy letters about both of their activities and travels in Asia.  Annual Christmas letters for the years 1951 through 1980 detail the family life of the Fahses and is the primary source of information about their lives during the period 1951-1961.    The files relating to the biography (or biographies) of Charles Burton Fahs all draw from the same material and build upon each other.  Jamie’s first biography was based on the oral history interview of Burton conducted by Caroline Bailey at the time of the donation of Burton’s library to Earlham College.  To this she added an extensive chronology of his life and selected correspondence and writings.  Finally Jamie and her daughter Barbara attempted a full biography, a draft of which is included.  Jamie also corresponded with Burton’s colleagues and their friends for comments on the biography draft and for additional information to enhance the story.  Burton’s later years are chronicled in Jamie’s journal, found in Box 4, Folder 56. The four folders of condolences and the programs and readings from the memorial services (Box 3, Folders 35-40) offer a perspective on Burton’s interactions and relationships with many colleagues and friends, as well as his impact on Japanese studies, American-Japanese cultural relationships, and international relations.   A scrapbook (Box 5, Folder 63) about Burton’s childhood, created by his mother Sophie, contains his parents’ letters and notes about Burton’s infancy and childhood, letters from Harvey to his children during his travels, and childhood and teenage letters to Harvey from Burton.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Atlantic Studies
Ancestor Notes: In late 1970 the officers of the Rockefeller Foundation allocated $300,000 to launch a program of grants to individuals engaged in the study of America's "cultural heritage." The following year, they appropriated an additional $500,000 to support similar initiatives on an institutional level.  Taking shape in a time of political, social, and cultural ferment, the American Cultural Heritage Program broadly aspired to "provide an alternative" to the "cynicism" and "self-doubt" that seemed to characterize Americans' understanding of their nation and their past. The alternative the officers envisioned was no simple-minded recitation of American myths, but rather a careful and creative reexamination of America's heritage "in the light of present problems." Greater self-understanding would lead to greater "awareness among Americans of their historical and cultural interdependence," a necessary first step to surmounting the problems that divided them. Such a critical reappraisal would also be a worthy contribution to the approaching national bicentennial commemoration.  The Cultural Heritage Program sought out promising younger scholars in the humanities and social sciences and particularly valued creative and interdisciplinary approaches. "Intellectual excellence, broad social commitment, and an imaginative approach" were the criteria that would guide institutional grants. With both the individual and institutional grants, the Foundation's goal was to "make an important contribution to the self-understanding of America's populace," and then to help shape the future by disseminating these new views of the past through formal and informal educational programs.  The projects funded vary widely but are notable for the impetus they display to seek out new questions and new ways of answering them. The question of "identities" and the contributions of minorities to the American nation were primary areas of study. Grantees studied transitions in Alaskan Eskimo life, Emancipation Day celebrations, Chinese workers in Oregon, recent immigrant communities, the role of black religion, and the works of black and women writers. The grants favored projects that sought to apply new disciplines and new techniques to the consideration of American culture. Through oral histories and field research, historians and others used the tools of anthropology to understand their own society. Oral history projects documented labor unrest in the Midwest, southern politicians, and American music, among other topics. On an institutional level, American Cultural Heritage grants launched major centers for the study of Atlantic, Southern, and Appalachian history.  Film, television production, and photographic studies make up another segment of these grants. Projects funded include photographic studies of the American farm, of four Texas counties, of grassroots Christianity, and of blacks in America. Films on folk traditions and television productions on the history of a New England mill town and on the social history of technology in America also received support. The University of Iowa received funding for a program to integrate the study of film and American civilization.  While some projects, like the Atlantic Studies Center at Johns Hopkins University, received major funding and some grants went to well-established scholars and institutions, the foundation's concern to cast its grants widely is striking. In assessing a grant to collect a history of the Gros Ventre tribe, for example, the foundation officer noted that while they could look for someone with "fancier credentials," they might also give "direct and substantial encouragement" to this "diligent amateur." The foundation also was concerned, in redressing the historical record, that the story be told by those who had lived it. The focus on oral history reflects this interest, but the concern was really a broader one to empower minorities to interpret their own heritage. Officers carefully considered a scholar's rapport with the community under study and gave extra weight to a shared regional or ethnic background. They favored one proposal, for example, because it presented the "possibility of furthering Southern Studies by people from this region, in this region." Some grants trained individuals in techniques that could then be brought back to the community.  The smallest grant - for $615 - allowed a scholar to complete a study of the black poet and novelist Jean Toomer. As the final grant report noted, people were impressed that "of all the RF's worldwide activities, . . . we could still take time to make such a small grant for such an obscure project."  While the American Cultural Heritage Program was a limited initiative, it is interesting to see the ways it intersected with and helped shape new initiatives in historical study. It encouraged interdisciplinary and particularly anthropological approaches to historical questions, supported the study of folklore, family history, religion, labor history, women's studies, community and regional studies, and embraced the application of new media to the presentation of traditional subjects. That these approaches are commonplace in textbooks today attests in some measure to the program's success. Researchers may also find in these files reflections of present-day concerns with cultural identity, heritage, and meaning.

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey - Johns, Ethel, "A Study of Present Status of the Negro Woman in Nursing" - NEN-2
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.

Title: Massachusetts Department of Mental Diseases
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Confidential Projects
Ancestor Notes: Following a 1939 tour of Latin America, Rockefeller sent a memorandum to President Franklin D. Roosevelt that expressed concern over Nazi influence in that region and recommended a program of U.S. cooperation and assistance to raise the standard of living in Latin America and to improve relations between the nations of the western hemisphere. President Roosevelt responded by appointing Rockefeller to head a new program that became the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs. Following the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, the agency coordinated the strategic defense of the region in the fields of information, economics, health, sanitation, agriculture, transportation, and culture and actively worked to frustrate Axis propaganda campaigns and economic designs on Latin America.  This subseries includes 6 cubic feet of correspondence and 19 cubic feet of bound printed material such as reports, newsletters, circulars issued by the various divisions of the OCIAA, and a complete set of "En Guardia," a Spanish-language picture magazine about the war that was produced and distributed by the OCIAA. There are also 15 reels of microfilm containing office correspondence: 6 reels of abstracts of incoming correspondence and 9 reels of complete outgoing correspondence. This correspondence may duplicate some of that within the paper files, but it does include additional correspondence as well.  Also found in this subseries are 61 motion picture films produced and distributed under the auspices of the OCIAA during the years 1940-1944. There is a substantial amount of documentation about the films in the papers of this series. These films appear to be NAR's personal copies. In 1942 the CIAA contracted with Walt Disney to produce 18 films, all of which exist at the Archive Center. The Julien Bryan films were produced for a primary and secondary level school audience. The films are in English or Spanish and address health, education, and cultural issues. The films are presented by the CIAA and are live-action in presentation unless otherwise noted.

Title: Report Drafts - Heilbroner, Robert
Ancestor: Subpanel VII: The Moral Framework of National Purpose (series)
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, papers, drafts, and final reports. Organization files, which are brief, concern the planning of subpanel activities. Membership files, as well as the correspondence that accompanies files in the Papers section, document discussions and writing on issues considered by the subpanel. The Papers files provide comprehensive presentations of the views of various subpanel experts on selected topics. Meeting files contain summaries and sometimes minute of subpanel discussions of issues. The Reports files, containing several drafts of each report, show the progressive synthesizing of the views of a subpanel's members.

Title: Cairns, Hugh H. - (Neurosurgery)
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: University of Illinois - Neurology
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Public Spaces Project
Component Notes: Project For Public Spaces, Inc.
Ancestor Notes: This subseries represents the overwhelming majority of the collection. It provides documentation of the Association's plans to redevelop and revitalize Lower Manhattan as a powerful business and financial center and to transform the community through a broadening residential population and growing opportunities for all the amenities of residential life including art, education, entertainment, health care, and many critical projects such as the World Trade Center, the Brooklyn Bridge Southeast and Southwest redevelopment areas, the heliport, Manhattan Landing, Nassau Street Mall, South Street Seaport and other downtown museums, community organizations such as the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and the Lower Manhattan Marketing Association, Murry Bergtraum High School and the downtown campus of Pace University (identified as Pace College), a variety of traffic and transportation improvements, as well as DLMA's involvement with the Lower Manhattan Project and the 1993 "Plan for Lower Manhattan." These files also document the Association's interest in and recommendation of several major projects that never came to fruition such as Westway and the Lower Manhattan Expressway.

Title: Cornell University - Civil Liberties
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biological Research
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Curriculum Vitae and General Career Information
Ancestor Notes: Folders in Series 2 document Burton’s varied career as an academic, a diplomat, and a foundation officer.  There is minimal documentation for his tenure at Pomona College, the Office of Strategic Services and later Department of State, Muhlenberg College, and Grolier, Inc.  More detailed information exists for his five years at Miami University, and extensive documentation is included for his career at the Rockefeller Foundation and the Embassy of the United States in Tokyo, Japan.    The Rockefeller Foundation diaries are an incomplete set and are draft versions of the final diaries filed with the Rockefeller Foundation and found in their archives.  The drafts do not appear to differ significantly from the final versions.  Of interest in this series is Fahs’s report to John Marshall chronicling his train trip from Paris to Kyoto in 1934 (Box 6, Folder 85).  The many reports and memoranda written by Fahs while at the Rockefeller Foundation and at Miami University offer his opinions on education, international study, and cultural exchange and evaluations of proposed changes to study abroad programs and support of universities in developing nations.  The invitations and related materials from his time at the Embassy in Japan are also important items from his diplomatic career.  Researchers interested in the early career of Charles Burton Fahs should also explore the correspondence files in Series 1 dated from this period; during his early career, there was an overlap between Fahs’s personal and professional life.  Series 4, Manuscripts, Publications, and Speeches contains the many articles and book reviews written by Fahs during his time at Pomona College, as well as other articles and speeches made throughout his career.
Resource Access Restriction: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biological Research
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: British Museum - Microfilm
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: University of Marseilles - Cardiology - (Gerard, Raymond, Equipment)
Ancestor Notes: Grants to French institutions were made primarily in the medical sciences field. The earliest grants were awarded for the campaign against tuberculosis, from which the Foundation's nursing program was created. The University of Paris was the major recipient of grants for the medical sciences. Funds were given for work by Th. Alajouanine, Jean Scherrer, and Clovis Vincent in neurology and neurosurgery and by Georges Heuyer in psychiatry. Funding was given to the Radium Institute in the 1920's, 1930's, and 1940's. The University of Lyons and the University of Strasbourg were also recipients of a relatively large number of medical sciences grants. In addition, there are files dealing with the Pearce report on French medical education which was part of a report on medical education throughout the world.   The Rockefeller Foundation also gave funding to a full range of humanities and social sciences programs. A large number of grants were given for work in philosophy. Grants were also given for a broad range of studies including art history and geography and ethnology. A number of humanities and social sciences grants were made to refugee scholars, including Richard Alewyn (German Literature), Elias Bickermann (Greek archeology), Kurt Sachs (music history), Julius Lewy (Assyriology), and Paul Schrecker (Philosophy).   The American Library in Paris and the Bibliotheque Nationale also received Foundation support.

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey - Report: "Colored Nurses in Public Health Work" - NEN-1
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Japan - Cultural and Educational Material
Ancestor Notes: Through correspondence, reports, and memoranda, this subseries documents Rockefeller's interest in and commitment to Asia. Rockefeller was deeply concerned about the need for increasing America's understanding and appreciation of the peoples of Asia. To that end, he was involved in the support of cultural exchange programs; the revival of the Japan Society; the formation of the Asia Society; the construction of Asia House, the Asia Society's New York City headquarters; and the construction of the International House of Japan in Tokyo. The files documenting the teaching of the English language in Japan (folders 452-455) reflect Rockefeller's belief in the importance of English to Japan's growth in the international community. Also included here are files relating to the Council on Economic and Cultural Affairs, Inc. (CECA), an organization established by Rockefeller in 1953 to stimulate and support economic and related activities focusing on Asia. Rockefeller's work for the John Foster Dulles peace mission to Japan in 1951 led to a renewed acquaintance with Shigeharu Matsumoto, with whom he had worked at the Institute of Pacific Relations conference in 1929. The Matsumoto and Rockefeller families became close friends. Included in this subseries are Rockefeller's report for Dulles and the State Department (folder 446), as well as correspondence between Matsumoto and JDR 3rd (folders 477-478). Also represented here are two commercial ventures developed by Rockefeller to sell in the United States quality merchandise manufactured in Asia, namely, Products of Asia, Inc. and Products of India, Inc. These companies, which were meant to increase trade and encourage cultural contact, were sold in 1965. | For additional Matsumoto family correspondence see series 3, subseries 2, folder 147.

Title: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Correspondence Re: Blocked Schilling Exchange Rates
Ancestor Notes: <emph render="bold">Series I. Ford Foundation Refugee Fund, 1952-1957</emph>   This series, arranged alphabetically, consists of Treasurer’s Department files relating to the administration of the Ford Foundation Refugee Fund. The files contain correspondence and memoranda between the Ford Foundation Treasurer’s Department and Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to whom the Foundation entrusted the administration of the fund. The documents detail financial and logistical matters such as the administration of grants (1952), establishing procedures for recording cancellation of appropriations (1952), and policy for the purchase and issuing of grant payments in blocked schillings (1952-1957). Also included are monthly financial reports prepared by the United Nations High Commissioner detailing the progress made in administering funds.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Physics - (Refugee Scholar, Franck, James)
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Aspira Inc.
Ancestor Notes: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.  Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.  The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.   A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.  The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

Title: Longstreth, Bevis
Ancestor Notes: Series II consists of correspondence, memoranda, agendas, minutes, rapporteur notes, reports, FCC filings, and press releases.   Contains the topical subject files. Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Cornell University - Civil Liberties
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy - Reprints and Pamphlets
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Matisse, Henri
Ancestor Notes: This subseries consists of an alphabetical file organized by artist name and a numeric file. Both document the acquisition, provenance, condition, cataloging, placement, and conservation of works of art. The alphabetical file primarily concerns pieces of modern art with documentation for each piece filed under the artist’s name. The alphabetical file also contains correspondence with dealers, conservators, galleries, museums, and other institutions regarding the acquisition, care, and loan of works of art. The numeric file is an arrangement created by Mrs. Uht to categorize nonmodern art. Works of art were first designated by geographic region and then arranged by accession number. The index for this file is in Appendix A. Works of art documented within this series were in Mr. Rockefeller’s collection at the time of his death in January 1979. Files pertaining to works of art that were no longer in the collection were transferred to the canceled art files (Subseries 6). The NAR art files were periodically sent to the Rockefeller family archives and were maintained there for several years. During that period some documents that do not belong in these files were placed in them.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biological Research
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: West Africa - Ivory Coast – Edwards visit
Ancestor Notes: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, press clippings and other records that document program development, grantmaking and grantee activities. Also included are records concerning the establishment, administration and daily operations of overseas offices. Numerous memos and reports written by Program Officers include vivid accounts of the political scene, current events and social and economic conditions in their host countries. Many reports contain general histories of regions or countries, as well as overviews of Foundation activities in these areas. Also included are files (restricted to Ford Foundation staff) concerning the opening of new offices in China and Zimbabwe, and on transferring the West Africa office from Lagos, Nigeria to Dakar, Senegal. The bulk of the series dates from the 1980s, though scattered memos and reports from the 1970s are also present.

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey - "A Study of the Present Status of the Negro Woman in Nursing" - (and Supplementary Material 1920-1925) - NEN-2
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.

Title: University of Manchester - Jefferson, Geoffrey - (Visit, Neurosurgery)
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: Refugee Scholars
Ancestor Notes: This series includes material for grants given to organizations that are national in scope but that fall outside the Foundation's established program divisions. Files are organized alphabetically. This series includes documentation of grants given as the result of the founder's designation and grants to such institutions as the American Baptist Home Mission Society, the American Council on Education, Biological Abstracts, a bird refuge in Louisiana, the Bureau of Municipal Research, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, the National Research Council, and prominent universities such as Johns Hopkins, Harvard and Yale. Also included in this series are files on the Foundation's support of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced Foreign Scholars and its support for Refugee Scholars during the 1930s and 1940s.

Title: University of Illinois - Epilepsy - (Gibbs, Frederick A.) - Reports
Ancestor Notes: Most of the records in this subseries date from the 1950's and 1960's. Among the institutions which received a number of grants from the Foundation were Columbia, Harvard, Johns Hopkins University, Tulane, University of California and Yale. Fields which the Foundation supported reasonably heavily included psychiatry and neurology and genetics and population control. In addition, emphasis was placed on problems in American and international medical education and curriculum development. Some grants were also given for programs relating to community medicine.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Tis Tisdale, W.E. "Report of a Visit to Scientific Institutions in China,"
Ancestor Notes: From 1913 to 1928 the Foundation's interests in China were directed by the China Medical Board, a division of the foundation. In 1928 the China Medical Board was separately incorporated and the functions continued by the Foundation were transferred to the Foundation's Division of Medical Education. Series 601 contains material after 1928, except for the Historical Records, which go back to 1913. Although the bulk of the material originated before 1945, there is also correspondence as late as 1960. The material consists of correspondence, memos, and reports relating to specific grants, and reports of a general nature which are filed in the 601 (General) section. A section on program and policy contains administrative and policy information in various forms.   Major areas of interest were agriculture and rural economics, public health and medicine. Grants were made predominantly to hospitals, universities and institutes of research. Of special interest are the files on rural reconstruction, the Mass Education movement, and the Peking Union Medical College. | For a more complete view of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China the records of the China Medical Board, Record Group 4 and of the China Medical Board, Inc. Collection should be consulted. Correspondence and reports can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2.   See also - 6.1 Field Office-Paris.

Title: Harvard University - Kelsen, Hans - (Refugee Scholar, Political Science)
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).
