Rockefeller, Jr. Personal</extref>  <extref href="../FA336/overview">FA336 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller</extref>  <extref href="../FA337/overview">FA337 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Abby Rockefeller Mauze </extref> | Record Group 2 of the David Rockefeller Papers contains his personal files dated 1918 to 1961 from the Rockefeller family office, known as the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR). The office was located in Rockefeller Center on the 56th floor of the main building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, contemporaneously referred to as the RCA Building.   Mr. Rockefeller’s personal files begin with his formative years and education, documenting his early interest in science and his family’s extensive travels. But the focus of this record group is the 15 years following his service during World War II in the U.S. Army, when David Rockefeller was establishing himself in the arenas of banking, international business, and philanthropy. While his personal and philanthropic activities are well represented in the files, the business records of his 35-year career with Chase Bank are not part of this collection.  The largest portion of this record group comprises 21 boxes of personal correspondence that date from the immediate post-war period until 1961. Mostly unsolicited, these letters come from friends and acquaintances from across the globe and amply illustrate the vast range of relationships he cultivated through the years. Mr. Rockefeller often heard from individuals he met during his wartime service in France and Algiers—which was, in his own words, “the beginning of a networking process that I would follow throughout my life.”* Correspondents of note include Alfred Barr, Jr., Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, Allen and John Foster Dulles, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Dag Hammarskjold, General George C. Marshall, Robert Moses, Arthur Sulzberger, and William Zorach.  Personal correspondence with his parents, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, dates from 1925 until his graduation from Harvard University in 1936, and later with solely his father following Abby’s death in 1948. While there are a handful of files related to David Rockefeller’s wedding to Margaret McGrath and their honeymoon in Wyoming, there is no correspondence between the two prior to their marriage in 1940. Likewise, there is little to no correspondence with his sister and four brothers. Correspondence regarding his children remains closed to research during their respective lifetimes.  Among topics of note in this record group is David Rockefeller’s close association with Harvard University that spans several decades. This includes folders on his financial support of the institution, as well as his lengthy service on its Board of Overseers. Additionally, folders on his 25th class reunion in 1961—for which he was elected Chief Marshall of the event—are complemented by details of his efforts to mount a special art exhibition for the occasion. Other aspects of his lifelong love of art are evident in the folders on the Museum of Modern Art, which his mother co-founded and on whose board Mr. Rockefeller served starting in 1948. Furthermore, information on the origins of his own art collecting is found in Folders 210-217.  From a young age, David Rockefeller fully embraced his family’s tradition of extensive travel. His 1932 handwritten accounts of a biking trip in England before starting college detailed the summer adventure in letters home to his parents (Folder 437). In 1935, he toured dozens of European art museums with close friend Richard Gilder, his Harvard roommate who later died while serving as a combat pilot in World War II. During that trip, Richard wrote a particularly poignant letter to Abby Rockefeller that describes their summer travels through Europe and focuses on the ominous developments in Germany as the continent headed toward war (Folder 441).  Lastly, this record group includes personal and quasi-professional files from 1959 to 1981 that the Chase Manhattan Bank transferred to the family office following David Rockefeller’s retirement in 1981. These are mostly chronological, event-specific folders.  * Rockefeller, David, Memoirs, New York: Random House, 2002, page 122.

Title: Internal History 4 -- Financial and Statistical Record -- Foundation Grants and Projects -- Memoranda and Program-Related Investment Report
Ancestor: Ford Foundation History Project, Subject Files (series)
Ancestor Notes: The Ford Foundation History Project Subject Files include correspondence, memoranda, grant proposals, reports, meeting materials, and notes. The History Project Subject Files document the Foundation’s broad-based, issue-focused efforts aimed at education and educational reform, international studies and relations, development planning and management, and arts and culture, among others. The Subject Files include program management materials, budget reports, and International Division administrative and operational files.  Also within this series are the Ford Foundation internal history files outlined by Dr. Sutton in chapter and section order. These files contain notes and background information on the early history of the Foundation and the formation of its international programs. Biographical information on the Foundation’s original trustees and staff, initial budgeting demands, program considerations and later developments shaped the structure of Dr. Sutton’s history outline. The Sutton/McCarthy History Text Files consist of the chapters that Dr. Sutton and his research assistant, Nancy McCarthy, composed using the materials found within this series. Some of these chapters also double as independent Foundation reports.

Title: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Correspondence (2 of 2)
Ancestor Notes: <emph render="bold">Series I. Ford Foundation Refugee Fund, 1952-1957</emph>   This series, arranged alphabetically, consists of Treasurer’s Department files relating to the administration of the Ford Foundation Refugee Fund. The files contain correspondence and memoranda between the Ford Foundation Treasurer’s Department and Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to whom the Foundation entrusted the administration of the fund. The documents detail financial and logistical matters such as the administration of grants (1952), establishing procedures for recording cancellation of appropriations (1952), and policy for the purchase and issuing of grant payments in blocked schillings (1952-1957). Also included are monthly financial reports prepared by the United Nations High Commissioner detailing the progress made in administering funds.

Title: Reischauer, Robert K. - (Far Eastern Studies)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey - "A Study of the Present Status of the Negro Woman in Nursing" - (and Supplementary Material 1920-1924) - NEN-2
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.

Title: Special Letter File (C)
Component Notes: Collection of letters set aside by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. as of particular significance.
Ancestor: John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Personal Papers - Correspondence (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: Subseries 1, Correspondence, is comprised of four sections: Personal Correspondence; Office Correspondence; Letterbooks (compiled by Raymond B. Fosdick), and Special Letter File.  The Personal Correspondence section contains incoming and outgoing correspondence, arranged alphabeticaly by correspondent. Significant correspondents includes JDR, Sr. (1901-1936), Laura Spelman Rockefeller (1891-1915), and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1901-1946).  The correspondence between Abby and JDR, Jr. consists of carbon transcriptions of select letters; some letters were edited prior to being transcribed. It is believed that JDR, Jr. selected the letters for transcription and destroyed others. The letters reveal an intense devotion and interdependence between husband and wife.  The correspondence between JDR, Jr. and his father spans the years 1901 to 1936 and provides an unbroken record of their daily communications. Senior's letters also appear in the Office Correspondence and Letterbooks sections of Subseries 1, and in Record Group 1 of the Rockefeller Family Archives, which is the papers of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.  The letterbooks in this subseries were compiled by Fosdick during the research phase or his work on "John D. Rockefeller, Jr: A Portrait" (1956). They contain selections from JDR, Jr.'s correspondence. The letterbooks are arranged by subjects which correspond to the final chapter headings. Material related to the compilation of these letterbooks is located in Subseries 5, Biographical Works, together with information about the so-called "Nevins books," assembled by Senior's biographer, Allan Nevins.  The Special Letter File section is arranged alphabeticaly by correspondent. Correspondents include Nelson W. Aldrich (1904-1910), Andrew Carnegie (1903-1914), Alexis Carrel (1914-1931), Winston Churchill (1909-1946), Henry C. Frick (1908-1919), Charles Evans Hughes (1916-1920), Charles A. Lindbergh (1928-1931), Ignace Jan Paderewski (1916), John Singer Sargent (1917), Woodrow Wilson (1903-1904), and Wendell L. Wilkie (1940). This file was created and maintained by JDR, Jr.'s office staff.
Parent Collection: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records

Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Atlantic Studies - Evaluation
Ancestor Notes: In late 1970 the officers of the Rockefeller Foundation allocated $300,000 to launch a program of grants to individuals engaged in the study of America's "cultural heritage." The following year, they appropriated an additional $500,000 to support similar initiatives on an institutional level.  Taking shape in a time of political, social, and cultural ferment, the American Cultural Heritage Program broadly aspired to "provide an alternative" to the "cynicism" and "self-doubt" that seemed to characterize Americans' understanding of their nation and their past. The alternative the officers envisioned was no simple-minded recitation of American myths, but rather a careful and creative reexamination of America's heritage "in the light of present problems." Greater self-understanding would lead to greater "awareness among Americans of their historical and cultural interdependence," a necessary first step to surmounting the problems that divided them. Such a critical reappraisal would also be a worthy contribution to the approaching national bicentennial commemoration.  The Cultural Heritage Program sought out promising younger scholars in the humanities and social sciences and particularly valued creative and interdisciplinary approaches. "Intellectual excellence, broad social commitment, and an imaginative approach" were the criteria that would guide institutional grants. With both the individual and institutional grants, the Foundation's goal was to "make an important contribution to the self-understanding of America's populace," and then to help shape the future by disseminating these new views of the past through formal and informal educational programs.  The projects funded vary widely but are notable for the impetus they display to seek out new questions and new ways of answering them. The question of "identities" and the contributions of minorities to the American nation were primary areas of study. Grantees studied transitions in Alaskan Eskimo life, Emancipation Day celebrations, Chinese workers in Oregon, recent immigrant communities, the role of black religion, and the works of black and women writers. The grants favored projects that sought to apply new disciplines and new techniques to the consideration of American culture. Through oral histories and field research, historians and others used the tools of anthropology to understand their own society. Oral history projects documented labor unrest in the Midwest, southern politicians, and American music, among other topics. On an institutional level, American Cultural Heritage grants launched major centers for the study of Atlantic, Southern, and Appalachian history.  Film, television production, and photographic studies make up another segment of these grants. Projects funded include photographic studies of the American farm, of four Texas counties, of grassroots Christianity, and of blacks in America. Films on folk traditions and television productions on the history of a New England mill town and on the social history of technology in America also received support. The University of Iowa received funding for a program to integrate the study of film and American civilization.  While some projects, like the Atlantic Studies Center at Johns Hopkins University, received major funding and some grants went to well-established scholars and institutions, the foundation's concern to cast its grants widely is striking. In assessing a grant to collect a history of the Gros Ventre tribe, for example, the foundation officer noted that while they could look for someone with "fancier credentials," they might also give "direct and substantial encouragement" to this "diligent amateur." The foundation also was concerned, in redressing the historical record, that the story be told by those who had lived it. The focus on oral history reflects this interest, but the concern was really a broader one to empower minorities to interpret their own heritage. Officers carefully considered a scholar's rapport with the community under study and gave extra weight to a shared regional or ethnic background. They favored one proposal, for example, because it presented the "possibility of furthering Southern Studies by people from this region, in this region." Some grants trained individuals in techniques that could then be brought back to the community.  The smallest grant - for $615 - allowed a scholar to complete a study of the black poet and novelist Jean Toomer. As the final grant report noted, people were impressed that "of all the RF's worldwide activities, . . . we could still take time to make such a small grant for such an obscure project."  While the American Cultural Heritage Program was a limited initiative, it is interesting to see the ways it intersected with and helped shape new initiatives in historical study. It encouraged interdisciplinary and particularly anthropological approaches to historical questions, supported the study of folklore, family history, religion, labor history, women's studies, community and regional studies, and embraced the application of new media to the presentation of traditional subjects. That these approaches are commonplace in textbooks today attests in some measure to the program's success. Researchers may also find in these files reflections of present-day concerns with cultural identity, heritage, and meaning.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Personal Correspondence - Named - de Lorey, Eustache
Ancestor: Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Papers - Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Correspondence (series)
Ancestor Notes: The bulk of Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's personal and professional correspondence (1882-1957) is located in Subseries 1, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Correspondence. Major correspondents include Abby's sister, Lucy Truman Aldrich, with whom Abby corresponded at length for thirty years; siblings Nelson, Edward, Stuart, William, Richard, Winthrop, and Elsie; and her six children: Abby (Babs), John Davison 3rd, Nelson, Laurance, Winthrop, and David. The correspondence between Abby and David Rockefeller remains closed. For what survives of Abby's letters to John D. Rockefeller, Jr., consult the John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Papers in Record Group 2, Series Z of the Rockefeller Family Archives.  Abby's correspondence with her brothers (Elsie Aldrich is not a primary correspondent) fills six folders. Letters reveal the friendly rapport and mutual respect that existed between the Aldrich siblings. They also provide information on Abby's occasional anonymous donations to projects in Boston and Providence for which her brothers sought her support. William, who was an architect in Boston, shared Abby's aesthetic interests and often recommended to her the purchase of paintings and furniture.  Among her children, Abby wrote most frequently to Winthrop Rockefeller, especially during the years of his army service (1941-1945) in World War II. Letters (1916-1948) from Babs to her mother include passionate appeals to return home from summer camp and accounts of sightseeing in Europe in 1920-1921 with her aunt, Lucy Truman Aldrich.  There are thirteen letters (1887-1909, n.d.) to Abby from her mother, Abby Pearce Chapman Aldrich. In a letter dated 8 March 1897, Mrs. Aldrich advises against a visit to New York, in case "Mamma Rockaffller . . . think you are chasing her son." Abby's letters to her mother are located in Subseries 5. There are thirteen letters (1887-1914, n.d.) to Abby from her father, Nelson W. Aldrich. Some are brief notes enclosed with checks; others display a rare sensitivity. Writing in the 1890s to his now teen-age daughter, the Senator acknowledges impending changes: "Your letter reminds me that very soon I shall not be able to deal with you as a little girl to be disposed of without consultation but that you will have to be treated with as a young lady, with wants and demands."  Other correspondents include Italianist Bernard Berenson, writing in 1927 from I Tatti; archaeologist James Henry Breasted, describing the recently unearthed tomb of King Tutankhamen; landscape architect Beatrice Ferrand, and painters Henri Matisse (two letters, 1932, 1933), Georgia O'Keefe, Walter Pach, and Peter Blume. Letters (1929-1937) from Eustache de Lorey of the Institut Français d'Archéologie et d'Art Musulmans discuss recent exhibitions, various pieces of Persian and Indian art, and modern pictures de Lorey envisioned for the Museum of Modern Art.  Also housed in Subseries 1 are twenty-four folders of Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) correspondence (1929-1945, 1947). This is largely Abby's incoming correspondence from museum staff relating to exhibitions and loans, personnel and financial matters, the War Veterans' Art Center, and modern movement in art. Major correspondents include Abby's financial adviser Arthur W. Packard, MoMA Director Alfred Barr, A. Conger Goodyear (President of MoMA), Monroe Wheeler (Director of Exhibitions and Publications), Stephen C. Clark (Chairman of the Board), Frances Hawkins (Secretary), James Thrall Soby (Director of Paintings and Sculpture), and John E. Abbott (Executive Vice President). Stephen Clark's moving tribute to Abby's moral leadership of the museum during the war years is housed in Subseries 7, Chase Biography Files, in folder 339.  The General Office File (1909-1955), a correspondence file maintained by John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s office staff, contains information on Mrs. Rockefeller's charitable activities.   | For Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's correspondence regarding her philanthropic work, see Subseries 4 - Philanthropy Files.  For Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's correspondence to her mother Abby Pearce Chapman Aldrich, and other Aldrich and Greene family correspondence, see Subseries 5 - Aldrich/Greene Family Papers.  For Abby Aldrich Rockefeller's correspondence to John D. Rockefeller, Jr., see the Rockefeller Family Archives, Record Group 2 - Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller, Series Z - John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal Papers.

Title: Bradley Home (Equipment)
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Correspondence from Richard E. Shope. Report on Participation by NaMRU #2 in Okinawa invasion
Component Notes: 80 pages and line map of areas in Okinawa in which observations were made.
Ancestor Notes: Late in 1941 Dr. Rivers organized a research unit for the United States Navy at The Rockefeller Institute Hospital, for the treatment of Navy-personnel suffering from certain specified diseases which were to be studied and which fit into the research program of the Institute Hospital. The diseases included streptococcus infections, cirrhosis of the liver and hepatitis.  In October 1943 Dr. Rivers visited the South Pacific and plans were made to establish a Naval Medical Research Unit Laboratory on Guam, in order to study diseases of the area in preparation for health needs of the Navy.   | Primarily the correspondence of Thomas Milton Rivers with various correspondents.

Title: Aspira Inc.
Component Notes: Proposals for leadership development and educational support program for Hispanic youth.
Ancestor Notes: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.  Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.  The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.   A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.  The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

Title: American Council of Learned Societies - Microphotography
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: "Civil Rights: The Negro Movement for Equal Opportunity" -- Discussion Paper Drafts, Comments
Ancestor Notes: Mr. Edley’s files comprise the largest series in this collection. A limited amount of chronological correspondence is available for the period from July 1968 to March 1969. The largest group of records, Mr. Edley’s subject files, have been arranged in alphabetical order. Mr. Edley’s files reflect his position in charge of Government and Law grant-making, including documents related to the Foundation’s work in the area of Corrections. The documents, which date between 1964 and 1973, include memoranda on prison education programs, correspondence about and results from a Foundation-funded survey of state correctional research capabilities, discussion papers, and background information.

Title: Special Letter File (L)
Component Notes: Collection of letters set aside by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. as of particular significance.
Ancestor: John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Personal Papers - Correspondence (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: Subseries 1, Correspondence, is comprised of four sections: Personal Correspondence; Office Correspondence; Letterbooks (compiled by Raymond B. Fosdick), and Special Letter File.  The Personal Correspondence section contains incoming and outgoing correspondence, arranged alphabeticaly by correspondent. Significant correspondents includes JDR, Sr. (1901-1936), Laura Spelman Rockefeller (1891-1915), and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1901-1946).  The correspondence between Abby and JDR, Jr. consists of carbon transcriptions of select letters; some letters were edited prior to being transcribed. It is believed that JDR, Jr. selected the letters for transcription and destroyed others. The letters reveal an intense devotion and interdependence between husband and wife.  The correspondence between JDR, Jr. and his father spans the years 1901 to 1936 and provides an unbroken record of their daily communications. Senior's letters also appear in the Office Correspondence and Letterbooks sections of Subseries 1, and in Record Group 1 of the Rockefeller Family Archives, which is the papers of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.  The letterbooks in this subseries were compiled by Fosdick during the research phase or his work on "John D. Rockefeller, Jr: A Portrait" (1956). They contain selections from JDR, Jr.'s correspondence. The letterbooks are arranged by subjects which correspond to the final chapter headings. Material related to the compilation of these letterbooks is located in Subseries 5, Biographical Works, together with information about the so-called "Nevins books," assembled by Senior's biographer, Allan Nevins.  The Special Letter File section is arranged alphabeticaly by correspondent. Correspondents include Nelson W. Aldrich (1904-1910), Andrew Carnegie (1903-1914), Alexis Carrel (1914-1931), Winston Churchill (1909-1946), Henry C. Frick (1908-1919), Charles Evans Hughes (1916-1920), Charles A. Lindbergh (1928-1931), Ignace Jan Paderewski (1916), John Singer Sargent (1917), Woodrow Wilson (1903-1904), and Wendell L. Wilkie (1940). This file was created and maintained by JDR, Jr.'s office staff.
Parent Collection: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records

Title: Rockefeller Foundation - National Diet Library, Japan
Ancestor Notes: Folders in Series 2 document Burton’s varied career as an academic, a diplomat, and a foundation officer.  There is minimal documentation for his tenure at Pomona College, the Office of Strategic Services and later Department of State, Muhlenberg College, and Grolier, Inc.  More detailed information exists for his five years at Miami University, and extensive documentation is included for his career at the Rockefeller Foundation and the Embassy of the United States in Tokyo, Japan.    The Rockefeller Foundation diaries are an incomplete set and are draft versions of the final diaries filed with the Rockefeller Foundation and found in their archives.  The drafts do not appear to differ significantly from the final versions.  Of interest in this series is Fahs’s report to John Marshall chronicling his train trip from Paris to Kyoto in 1934 (Box 6, Folder 85).  The many reports and memoranda written by Fahs while at the Rockefeller Foundation and at Miami University offer his opinions on education, international study, and cultural exchange and evaluations of proposed changes to study abroad programs and support of universities in developing nations.  The invitations and related materials from his time at the Embassy in Japan are also important items from his diplomatic career.  Researchers interested in the early career of Charles Burton Fahs should also explore the correspondence files in Series 1 dated from this period; during his early career, there was an overlap between Fahs’s personal and professional life.  Series 4, Manuscripts, Publications, and Speeches contains the many articles and book reviews written by Fahs during his time at Pomona College, as well as other articles and speeches made throughout his career.

Title: New School for Social Research - Kogbetliantz, Ervand - (Refugee Scholar, Mathematics and Geophysics)
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Subject Analysis - Investments and Program-Related Investments
Ancestor Notes: This series contains correspondence, memos, policy and research reports, "Congressional Record" excerpts, press releases, news clippings, articles, and other printed material relating to tax reform legislation and its impact on foundations and on charitable giving. The Council's lobbying efforts, including its response to the Tax Reform Act of 1969, are documented in the correspondence of Council executives David F. Freeman, Robert F. Goheen, and Eugene C. Struckhoff with politicians, members, and tax consultants that will be found throughout the series. Approximately 20 percent of the Tax Reform Act of 1969 dealt directly with foundations. The act, which extended and intensified Internal Revenue Service supervision of foundations and helped eliminate what some perceived as abuses in the management of foundations, had serious effects on foundations and on philanthropic giving. Files in this series discuss the impact or potential impact of changes in such areas as net investment income, self-dealing, excise taxes, and income accumulation regulations. Information on Internal Revenue Code revisions and the effects of the Tax Reform Act of 1976 can also be found in this series.  Also housed here are files that offer insights into the Council's relationship with Congress. These files contain copies of proposed legislation in the House of Representatives and in the Senate; transcripts of House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee hearings; and correspondence with various members of Congress. Also included in the congressional files is a folder titled "Investigations of Foundations" (box 7, folder 61) that contains printed material regarding a number of congressional investigative committees, including the Special Committee to Investigate Tax Exempt Foundations (commonly known as the Reece Committee), whose chairman attempted in 1953-1954 to link foundations with the financing of communism in the United States.

Title: Barstow, F. Q.
Component Notes: New York, New York. Acme Oil Company; relations between executive and manufacturing committees; production; quality of oil; production of competitors.
Ancestor Notes: The business correspondence contains an avalanche of information about the far-flung activities of the Rockefeller empire. From all over the country and from around the world there flowed data, information, and rumor. Reports to the Executive Committee of Standard Oil showed how the firm dealt with the first really effective challenges to its international hegemony in the 1880s, the result of the discovery and exploitation of vast fields in Russia, developed by the Nobel interests. The task of keeping order in the industry was never-ending, as can be seen, for example, in the files from Standard executive John Archbold. The company's hold on the domestic transport of oil was threatened by a succession of competitors and opponents from time to time. For example, Archbold wrote to Rockefeller in 1886: "We learn today to our great surprise and disgust that Penna. RR is furnishing Tank cars to the Holdship pipe Line for shipment of crude oil East. Have telegraphed protest strongly."* Similarly, the international struggle required constant vigilance: "We are considering the question of sending somebody to the Far East . . . the Russians are making very aggressive efforts in these mkts."** By contrast, at moments when all was well within Standard's empire, Archbold could report what Rockefeller longed to hear: "pressing sales of refined in all directions as vigorously as possible. Everything moving along quietly and well."***   Equally important were the continuous summaries of quantitative data, the informational lifeblood of a modern business enterprise. Reports on stocks of crude oil, kerosene, and lubricants came constantly from New Jersey, from Marseilles, from the Far East, and from all over the world. Data on productivity and profitability were especially prevalent, such as reports on the monthly yields of various products per hundred gallons of crude in Standard's different refineries around the country, including conclusions about the total value of the product, the cost of refining, and the net value of goods produced at each site. No detail seemed to be too small to require at least a summary for the firm's head, including data on the monthly amounts paid to Western Union in Cleveland for telegrams. Information on insurance, news of competitors' new or rumored refineries or transportation facilities, measures of performance by individual managers or refineries, real estate deals, and political and legal intelligence were generated in staggering volume. Important moments in history are here, such as the telegram from Standard's lawyer and lobbyist in Washington that brought John D. Rockefeller word of Senate passage of the Sherman Antitrust Act. "Senate has just passed the Judiciary Committee trust bill all amendments being voted down," J. H. Flagg wired Rockefeller at his residence at 4 W. 54th Street in Manhattan in April of 1890. "There was but little debate and only one Senator Blodgett of New Jersey voted against the bill."**** A little more than twenty years later, that act would be used to break up Standard Oil in the landmark Supreme Court case of 1911.   In these voluminous business files we see also the communications to their leader from many of the able lieutenants and associates in Standard, such as John Archbold, Henry Flagler, and Henry Folger. Here, in short, we can see the details of how the great Standard Oil Trust did its work.    Glenn Porter Director Hagley Museum and Library ----------------------------------- * Archbold to Rockefeller, October 5, 1886. Rockefeller Family Archives, hereafter Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. Rockefeller Archive Center. ** Archbold to Rockefeller, February 4, 1892. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. *** Archbold to Rockefeller, July 18, 1892. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. **** Flagg to Rockefeller, April 8, 1890. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 56. Folder 413.

Title: Aspira Inc.
Component Notes: Includes report and interview notes on self-help organizations in the Puerto Rican community, August 1960.
Ancestor Notes: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.  Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.  The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.   A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.  The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

Title: Public Opinion Polls
Component Notes: Political Situation in New York State, February 1960; voters in California, Illinois, New York, Pennsylvania & Texas, July 1960; New York State Political Surveys, October 1960.
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains a selection of polls and public opinion surveys conducted primarily in New York State, although a small selection concerns national issues. In most cases the polls were conducted by Political Analysis Associates of Princeton, New Jersey. Primarily, the surveys focus on Governor Rockefeller or are specific to an issue within New York State. However, some were undertaken in response to New York City issues, such as two surveys conducted in 1970 on the status of the New York City subway system and a phone survey of New York City Mayor John Lindsay's popularity. In some cases, accompanying memoranda may be found that analyze the poll data for the Governor. Note that this subseries is an incomplete aggregate of the polls conducted in New York State.

Title: Papers - Mc Keon, Richard - Paper VII-1 - "Responsibility as Sign and as Instrumentality"
Ancestor: Subpanel VII: The Moral Framework of National Purpose (series)
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, papers, drafts, and final reports. Organization files, which are brief, concern the planning of subpanel activities. Membership files, as well as the correspondence that accompanies files in the Papers section, document discussions and writing on issues considered by the subpanel. The Papers files provide comprehensive presentations of the views of various subpanel experts on selected topics. Meeting files contain summaries and sometimes minute of subpanel discussions of issues. The Reports files, containing several drafts of each report, show the progressive synthesizing of the views of a subpanel's members.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry - Andrews, Donald
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Report Drafts - General Material
Ancestor: Subpanel VII: The Moral Framework of National Purpose (series)
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, papers, drafts, and final reports. Organization files, which are brief, concern the planning of subpanel activities. Membership files, as well as the correspondence that accompanies files in the Papers section, document discussions and writing on issues considered by the subpanel. The Papers files provide comprehensive presentations of the views of various subpanel experts on selected topics. Meeting files contain summaries and sometimes minute of subpanel discussions of issues. The Reports files, containing several drafts of each report, show the progressive synthesizing of the views of a subpanel's members.

Title: University of Marseilles - Surgery - (Metras, Henri)
Ancestor Notes: Grants to French institutions were made primarily in the medical sciences field. The earliest grants were awarded for the campaign against tuberculosis, from which the Foundation's nursing program was created. The University of Paris was the major recipient of grants for the medical sciences. Funds were given for work by Th. Alajouanine, Jean Scherrer, and Clovis Vincent in neurology and neurosurgery and by Georges Heuyer in psychiatry. Funding was given to the Radium Institute in the 1920's, 1930's, and 1940's. The University of Lyons and the University of Strasbourg were also recipients of a relatively large number of medical sciences grants. In addition, there are files dealing with the Pearce report on French medical education which was part of a report on medical education throughout the world.   The Rockefeller Foundation also gave funding to a full range of humanities and social sciences programs. A large number of grants were given for work in philosophy. Grants were also given for a broad range of studies including art history and geography and ethnology. A number of humanities and social sciences grants were made to refugee scholars, including Richard Alewyn (German Literature), Elias Bickermann (Greek archeology), Kurt Sachs (music history), Julius Lewy (Assyriology), and Paul Schrecker (Philosophy).   The American Library in Paris and the Bibliotheque Nationale also received Foundation support.

Title: Rockefeller Foundation - Memoranda and Reports
Ancestor Notes: Folders in Series 2 document Burton’s varied career as an academic, a diplomat, and a foundation officer.  There is minimal documentation for his tenure at Pomona College, the Office of Strategic Services and later Department of State, Muhlenberg College, and Grolier, Inc.  More detailed information exists for his five years at Miami University, and extensive documentation is included for his career at the Rockefeller Foundation and the Embassy of the United States in Tokyo, Japan.    The Rockefeller Foundation diaries are an incomplete set and are draft versions of the final diaries filed with the Rockefeller Foundation and found in their archives.  The drafts do not appear to differ significantly from the final versions.  Of interest in this series is Fahs’s report to John Marshall chronicling his train trip from Paris to Kyoto in 1934 (Box 6, Folder 85).  The many reports and memoranda written by Fahs while at the Rockefeller Foundation and at Miami University offer his opinions on education, international study, and cultural exchange and evaluations of proposed changes to study abroad programs and support of universities in developing nations.  The invitations and related materials from his time at the Embassy in Japan are also important items from his diplomatic career.  Researchers interested in the early career of Charles Burton Fahs should also explore the correspondence files in Series 1 dated from this period; during his early career, there was an overlap between Fahs’s personal and professional life.  Series 4, Manuscripts, Publications, and Speeches contains the many articles and book reviews written by Fahs during his time at Pomona College, as well as other articles and speeches made throughout his career.
Resource Access Restriction: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

Title: University of Cambridge - Economics
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: ALA 160 - Supervisor of Rural Schools - Negro
Component Notes: Schools, segregation, faculty, students, buildings
Ancestor Access Restriction: Photographs, slides, and other images are open for scholarly research.  RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.
Ancestor Notes: The General Education Board (GEB) was established in 1903 by John D. Rockefeller to aid education in the U.S. "without distinction of race, sex or creed." The program included grants for endowment and general budgetary support of colleges and universities, support for special programs, fellowship and scholarship assistance to state school systems at all levels, and development of social and economic resources as a route to improved educational systems. Major colleges and universities across the U.S., as well as many small institutions in every state, received aid from the Board. The emphasis, however, was on the South and the education of Blacks. Offices were established in Richmond, Virginia, and Baton Rouge, Louisiana, to give GEB agents closer contact with southern communities. The Board was especially active in promoting the public school movement in the early part of the twentieth century. After 1940, programs other than those for southern education were brought to a close; funds were nearly exhausted by the 1950s, and the last appropriation was made in 1964.

Title: Japan - Cultural and Educational Material
Ancestor Notes: Through correspondence, reports, and memoranda, this subseries documents Rockefeller's interest in and commitment to Asia. Rockefeller was deeply concerned about the need for increasing America's understanding and appreciation of the peoples of Asia. To that end, he was involved in the support of cultural exchange programs; the revival of the Japan Society; the formation of the Asia Society; the construction of Asia House, the Asia Society's New York City headquarters; and the construction of the International House of Japan in Tokyo. The files documenting the teaching of the English language in Japan (folders 452-455) reflect Rockefeller's belief in the importance of English to Japan's growth in the international community. Also included here are files relating to the Council on Economic and Cultural Affairs, Inc. (CECA), an organization established by Rockefeller in 1953 to stimulate and support economic and related activities focusing on Asia. Rockefeller's work for the John Foster Dulles peace mission to Japan in 1951 led to a renewed acquaintance with Shigeharu Matsumoto, with whom he had worked at the Institute of Pacific Relations conference in 1929. The Matsumoto and Rockefeller families became close friends. Included in this subseries are Rockefeller's report for Dulles and the State Department (folder 446), as well as correspondence between Matsumoto and JDR 3rd (folders 477-478). Also represented here are two commercial ventures developed by Rockefeller to sell in the United States quality merchandise manufactured in Asia, namely, Products of Asia, Inc. and Products of India, Inc. These companies, which were meant to increase trade and encourage cultural contact, were sold in 1965. | For additional Matsumoto family correspondence see series 3, subseries 2, folder 147.

Component Notes: 1. Dr. Bertha Lutz, prominent feminine leader in Brazil, with Dr. Louise Stanley and Dr. Afranio Carvalho, Cabinet Chief to the Minister of Agriculture. 2. A convite do Dr. Josue de Castro, Chefe do Instituto de Nutricao no Brasil, a Dra. Louise Stanley, nutricionista norte-americana, dirigiu-se aos membros do Curso do Instituto de Nutricao durante a recente reuniao realisada na Santa Casa de Nisericordia. A palestra da Dra. Stanley sobre como os problemas de nutricao nos Estados Unidos tinham sido encarados e solucionados, despertou grande interesse entre os membres da Faculdade Nacional de Medicina que desenpenham atividades identicas neste paiz. A Dra. Stanley visita o Brasil a convite do Sr. Nelson Rockefeller e sob os auspicious da American International Association for Economic and Social Development (Associao Internacional Americana de Fomento Economico e Socail) a fim de colher inforacoes autoizades sobre a situacao alimentar e dos generos de nutricao no pais. 3. Dr. Louise Stanley and Dr. Josue de Castro, head of the Instituto de Nutricao, exchange a good neighbor handshake. 4. Title: University of Cambridge - Economics
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: Queens College - American Literature
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Public Opinion Polls
Component Notes: New York State Political Survey, February 1961; 1961 Election in New York City, April 1961; Governors Program - New York State, July 1961; New York City-Mayoralty, September & October 1961; Fallout Shelters, November 1961.
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains a selection of polls and public opinion surveys conducted primarily in New York State, although a small selection concerns national issues. In most cases the polls were conducted by Political Analysis Associates of Princeton, New Jersey. Primarily, the surveys focus on Governor Rockefeller or are specific to an issue within New York State. However, some were undertaken in response to New York City issues, such as two surveys conducted in 1970 on the status of the New York City subway system and a phone survey of New York City Mayor John Lindsay's popularity. In some cases, accompanying memoranda may be found that analyze the poll data for the Governor. Note that this subseries is an incomplete aggregate of the polls conducted in New York State.

Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Bradley Home (Equipment)
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Tensions in Development in the Western Hemisphere, Council on World Tensions, Bahia, Brazil, August 6-11, 1962.
Ancestor Notes: SERIES III, MEETING FILES (1958-1967), consists of 3 linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, notes, agendas, minutes, and background and meeting papers. This series includes all meetings except those of the Council on Foreign Relations and the International Broadcast Institute which are included in Series IV, ORGANIZATION FILES. Series II is made up of many different types of meetings: conferences, committees, seminars, colloquiums, formal and informal study groups, and briefings. Some were sponsored by the Ford Foundation and held internally, others resulted from Foundation grants and were held under the auspices of the grantees, while others matched Foundation interests and were attended by Mr. Slater in his capacity of staff member of the International Affairs program.

Title: Cornell University - Civil Liberties
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: de Bellard Pietri, Eugenio
Component Notes: bat echolocation; birds; National Speleological Society of Spain
Ancestor Notes: Items include letters to and from other scientists, colleagues, and friends; questions from the general public; requests for peer review of articles; and a few letters from family members. Correspondence with former students and fellow scientists often includes tidbits regarding experiments or projects as well as shared findings. Subject matter ranges from atomic bombs to animal pathology and psychological abilities to employment recommendations for former students and colleagues. A few candid photographs and machine print outs were attached to correspondence and have been left with the correspondence rather than separating such a small number of items and possibly losing valuable context.

Title: Communications Study
Ancestor Notes: Following a 1939 tour of Latin America, Rockefeller sent a memorandum to President Franklin D. Roosevelt that expressed concern over Nazi influence in that region and recommended a program of U.S. cooperation and assistance to raise the standard of living in Latin America and to improve relations between the nations of the western hemisphere. President Roosevelt responded by appointing Rockefeller to head a new program that became the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs. Following the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, the agency coordinated the strategic defense of the region in the fields of information, economics, health, sanitation, agriculture, transportation, and culture and actively worked to frustrate Axis propaganda campaigns and economic designs on Latin America.  This subseries includes 6 cubic feet of correspondence and 19 cubic feet of bound printed material such as reports, newsletters, circulars issued by the various divisions of the OCIAA, and a complete set of "En Guardia," a Spanish-language picture magazine about the war that was produced and distributed by the OCIAA. There are also 15 reels of microfilm containing office correspondence: 6 reels of abstracts of incoming correspondence and 9 reels of complete outgoing correspondence. This correspondence may duplicate some of that within the paper files, but it does include additional correspondence as well.  Also found in this subseries are 61 motion picture films produced and distributed under the auspices of the OCIAA during the years 1940-1944. There is a substantial amount of documentation about the films in the papers of this series. These films appear to be NAR's personal copies. In 1942 the CIAA contracted with Walt Disney to produce 18 films, all of which exist at the Archive Center. The Julien Bryan films were produced for a primary and secondary level school audience. The films are in English or Spanish and address health, education, and cultural issues. The films are presented by the CIAA and are live-action in presentation unless otherwise noted.

Title: Barstow, F. Q.
Component Notes: New York, New York. Acme Oil Company; relations between executive and manufacturing committees; production; quality of oil; production of competitors.
Ancestor Notes: The business correspondence contains an avalanche of information about the far-flung activities of the Rockefeller empire. From all over the country and from around the world there flowed data, information, and rumor. Reports to the Executive Committee of Standard Oil showed how the firm dealt with the first really effective challenges to its international hegemony in the 1880s, the result of the discovery and exploitation of vast fields in Russia, developed by the Nobel interests. The task of keeping order in the industry was never-ending, as can be seen, for example, in the files from Standard executive John Archbold. The company's hold on the domestic transport of oil was threatened by a succession of competitors and opponents from time to time. For example, Archbold wrote to Rockefeller in 1886: "We learn today to our great surprise and disgust that Penna. RR is furnishing Tank cars to the Holdship pipe Line for shipment of crude oil East. Have telegraphed protest strongly."* Similarly, the international struggle required constant vigilance: "We are considering the question of sending somebody to the Far East . . . the Russians are making very aggressive efforts in these mkts."** By contrast, at moments when all was well within Standard's empire, Archbold could report what Rockefeller longed to hear: "pressing sales of refined in all directions as vigorously as possible. Everything moving along quietly and well."***   Equally important were the continuous summaries of quantitative data, the informational lifeblood of a modern business enterprise. Reports on stocks of crude oil, kerosene, and lubricants came constantly from New Jersey, from Marseilles, from the Far East, and from all over the world. Data on productivity and profitability were especially prevalent, such as reports on the monthly yields of various products per hundred gallons of crude in Standard's different refineries around the country, including conclusions about the total value of the product, the cost of refining, and the net value of goods produced at each site. No detail seemed to be too small to require at least a summary for the firm's head, including data on the monthly amounts paid to Western Union in Cleveland for telegrams. Information on insurance, news of competitors' new or rumored refineries or transportation facilities, measures of performance by individual managers or refineries, real estate deals, and political and legal intelligence were generated in staggering volume. Important moments in history are here, such as the telegram from Standard's lawyer and lobbyist in Washington that brought John D. Rockefeller word of Senate passage of the Sherman Antitrust Act. "Senate has just passed the Judiciary Committee trust bill all amendments being voted down," J. H. Flagg wired Rockefeller at his residence at 4 W. 54th Street in Manhattan in April of 1890. "There was but little debate and only one Senator Blodgett of New Jersey voted against the bill."**** A little more than twenty years later, that act would be used to break up Standard Oil in the landmark Supreme Court case of 1911.   In these voluminous business files we see also the communications to their leader from many of the able lieutenants and associates in Standard, such as John Archbold, Henry Flagler, and Henry Folger. Here, in short, we can see the details of how the great Standard Oil Trust did its work.    Glenn Porter Director Hagley Museum and Library ----------------------------------- * Archbold to Rockefeller, October 5, 1886. Rockefeller Family Archives, hereafter Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. Rockefeller Archive Center. ** Archbold to Rockefeller, February 4, 1892. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. *** Archbold to Rockefeller, July 18, 1892. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 52. Folder 383. **** Flagg to Rockefeller, April 8, 1890. Archives. RG 1. Series C. Subseries B. Box 56. Folder 413.

Title: Imperial College of Science and Technology - Paneth, Fritz - (Refugee, Physical Chemistry)
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.
