Title: Johns Hopkins University - Atlantic Studies
Ancestor Notes: In late 1970 the officers of the Rockefeller Foundation allocated $300,000 to launch a program of grants to individuals engaged in the study of America's "cultural heritage." The following year, they appropriated an additional $500,000 to support similar initiatives on an institutional level.  Taking shape in a time of political, social, and cultural ferment, the American Cultural Heritage Program broadly aspired to "provide an alternative" to the "cynicism" and "self-doubt" that seemed to characterize Americans' understanding of their nation and their past. The alternative the officers envisioned was no simple-minded recitation of American myths, but rather a careful and creative reexamination of America's heritage "in the light of present problems." Greater self-understanding would lead to greater "awareness among Americans of their historical and cultural interdependence," a necessary first step to surmounting the problems that divided them. Such a critical reappraisal would also be a worthy contribution to the approaching national bicentennial commemoration.  The Cultural Heritage Program sought out promising younger scholars in the humanities and social sciences and particularly valued creative and interdisciplinary approaches. "Intellectual excellence, broad social commitment, and an imaginative approach" were the criteria that would guide institutional grants. With both the individual and institutional grants, the Foundation's goal was to "make an important contribution to the self-understanding of America's populace," and then to help shape the future by disseminating these new views of the past through formal and informal educational programs.  The projects funded vary widely but are notable for the impetus they display to seek out new questions and new ways of answering them. The question of "identities" and the contributions of minorities to the American nation were primary areas of study. Grantees studied transitions in Alaskan Eskimo life, Emancipation Day celebrations, Chinese workers in Oregon, recent immigrant communities, the role of black religion, and the works of black and women writers. The grants favored projects that sought to apply new disciplines and new techniques to the consideration of American culture. Through oral histories and field research, historians and others used the tools of anthropology to understand their own society. Oral history projects documented labor unrest in the Midwest, southern politicians, and American music, among other topics. On an institutional level, American Cultural Heritage grants launched major centers for the study of Atlantic, Southern, and Appalachian history.  Film, television production, and photographic studies make up another segment of these grants. Projects funded include photographic studies of the American farm, of four Texas counties, of grassroots Christianity, and of blacks in America. Films on folk traditions and television productions on the history of a New England mill town and on the social history of technology in America also received support. The University of Iowa received funding for a program to integrate the study of film and American civilization.  While some projects, like the Atlantic Studies Center at Johns Hopkins University, received major funding and some grants went to well-established scholars and institutions, the foundation's concern to cast its grants widely is striking. In assessing a grant to collect a history of the Gros Ventre tribe, for example, the foundation officer noted that while they could look for someone with "fancier credentials," they might also give "direct and substantial encouragement" to this "diligent amateur." The foundation also was concerned, in redressing the historical record, that the story be told by those who had lived it. The focus on oral history reflects this interest, but the concern was really a broader one to empower minorities to interpret their own heritage. Officers carefully considered a scholar's rapport with the community under study and gave extra weight to a shared regional or ethnic background. They favored one proposal, for example, because it presented the "possibility of furthering Southern Studies by people from this region, in this region." Some grants trained individuals in techniques that could then be brought back to the community.  The smallest grant - for $615 - allowed a scholar to complete a study of the black poet and novelist Jean Toomer. As the final grant report noted, people were impressed that "of all the RF's worldwide activities, . . . we could still take time to make such a small grant for such an obscure project."  While the American Cultural Heritage Program was a limited initiative, it is interesting to see the ways it intersected with and helped shape new initiatives in historical study. It encouraged interdisciplinary and particularly anthropological approaches to historical questions, supported the study of folklore, family history, religion, labor history, women's studies, community and regional studies, and embraced the application of new media to the presentation of traditional subjects. That these approaches are commonplace in textbooks today attests in some measure to the program's success. Researchers may also find in these files reflections of present-day concerns with cultural identity, heritage, and meaning.

Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Fordham University - Hess, Victor F. - (Refugee Scholar, Physics)
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: NET – proposals
Ancestor Notes: Correspondence, memoranda, agendas, reports and research materials compiled by Friendly on a variety of topics relating to broadcasting, telecommunications, journalism and law. There are substantial files on the early design and implementation of community antenna television (CATV, or cable television) systems, especially in the New York City region, satellite broadcast technology, and the Foundation-funded operations of public television stations and organizations including National Educational Television (NET) and the Public Broadcast Laboratory. Reports and memos from the Office of Public Broadcasting and Office of Communications (box 19, folders 8-12) illuminate staff thinking during the period when Foundation support for public television was dramatically reduced.

Title: Outgoing Correspondence - Santayana, George
Ancestor Notes: Series 2, Professional Correspondence, fills Boxes 4 through 8 and contains Strong's correspondence with philosophers and writers. Strong's correspondents include Bernard and Mary Berenson, Henri Bergson, Alfred Binet, John Dewey, G. Lowes Dickinson, John Galsworthy, William James, Arthur O. Lovejoy, John Masefield, G. E. Moore, Friedrich Paulsen (1 letter), Charles S. Peirce (2 letters), Ralph Barton Perry (2 letters), Walter Rauschenbusch, Bertrand Russell, George Santayana, F. C. S. Schiller, and Paul Shorey. Among his most faithful colleagues and critics were Durant Drake (Vassar College), Dickinson S. Miller (Columbia), James Bissett Pratt (Williams College), A. K. Rogers (Yale) and Roy Wood Sellars (University of Michigan). Strong's outgoing correspondence includes a packet entitled "My Letters to Philosophers" (1902-12).  George Santayana's correspondence with Strong, located in Series 2, is the largest single correspondence in the collection. The letters are uninterrupted for the period 1900 to 1939 and fill twenty folders. Most of the letters were written after 1912 during extended sojourns in France, Italy, Germany, and Spain. Santayana's letters are warm and full of personal anecdote, and report on the books he is reading as well as the progress of his own writings, including "The Realm of Matter" (1930), "The Realm of Truth" (1937), "The Realm of Spirit" (1940), and the novel, "The Last Puritan" (1939). Although they remained loyal friends, Strong and Santayana continually disagreed over the scope and limits of perception. Their philosophical differences gradually took on a personal edge. After a 1938 meeting in Rome, which led to an altercation, Santayana wrote that he and Strong had fallen "out of sympathy on almost every current subject." In 1939, he declared, "Your presuppositions as to what can and what cannot excite consciousness are not such as I feel any need of making." Strong's letters to Santayana fill three folders and consist mainly of transcript drafts of letters for the years 1930, 1932 and 1933 concerning philosophical subjects.  The letters of William James to Charles Strong fill seven folders and are largely uninterrupted for the period 1898 to 1910, the year of James' death. In his letters, James discusses materialism, his reactions to Strong's writings, books he is reading, his teaching load, travel plans, family life, and the precarious state of his health. He describes in 1905 his first encounter with French philosopher Henri Bergson. Writing on 6 February 1906 from Palo Alto, where he was lecturing at Stanford University, he gives a lively account of his reaction to the San Francisco earthquake. Strong's letters to James fill one folder. Two letters (1889), written from Berlin, offer a theory of materialism explaining the relationship between the mind and the body, in which the human mind is a product of natural processes. Strong's theory found formal expression in his first book, "Why the Mind has a Body" (1903).

Title: Endowment Management
Ancestor Notes: Series II consists of correspondence, memoranda, agendas, minutes, rapporteur notes, reports, FCC filings, and press releases.   Contains the topical subject files. Series II documents many of the activities and issues in which the Ford Foundation was involved: affirmative action within and outside of the Foundation; retrenchment and dependent organizations; Foundation self-evaluation and future program planning; public interest law; public television and the proposed Broadcaster's Nonprofit Satellite; foundation-government relations including public policy development, government and higher education research, and the Tax Reform Act of 1969; and decentralization of New York City schools.

Title: Society for Japanese Studies - Dilts, Marion M. - Report
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: University of Cambridge - Fajans, K. - (Refugee, Chemistry)
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey - Report: "Colored Nurses in Public Health Work" - NEN-1
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.

Title: Asia Society - Certificate of Incorporation
Ancestor Notes: Through correspondence, reports, and memoranda, this subseries documents Rockefeller's interest in and commitment to Asia. Rockefeller was deeply concerned about the need for increasing America's understanding and appreciation of the peoples of Asia. To that end, he was involved in the support of cultural exchange programs; the revival of the Japan Society; the formation of the Asia Society; the construction of Asia House, the Asia Society's New York City headquarters; and the construction of the International House of Japan in Tokyo. The files documenting the teaching of the English language in Japan (folders 452-455) reflect Rockefeller's belief in the importance of English to Japan's growth in the international community. Also included here are files relating to the Council on Economic and Cultural Affairs, Inc. (CECA), an organization established by Rockefeller in 1953 to stimulate and support economic and related activities focusing on Asia. Rockefeller's work for the John Foster Dulles peace mission to Japan in 1951 led to a renewed acquaintance with Shigeharu Matsumoto, with whom he had worked at the Institute of Pacific Relations conference in 1929. The Matsumoto and Rockefeller families became close friends. Included in this subseries are Rockefeller's report for Dulles and the State Department (folder 446), as well as correspondence between Matsumoto and JDR 3rd (folders 477-478). Also represented here are two commercial ventures developed by Rockefeller to sell in the United States quality merchandise manufactured in Asia, namely, Products of Asia, Inc. and Products of India, Inc. These companies, which were meant to increase trade and encourage cultural contact, were sold in 1965. | For additional Matsumoto family correspondence see series 3, subseries 2, folder 147.

Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Central Institute for the Deaf - De No, Lorente
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Nick Menzies memo - Meeting with the Yunnan Uplands Management (YUM) Program Leading Group
Ancestor Notes: Subseries documents Peter F. Geithner’s engagement with various China-related issues during the periods he served as Ford Foundation Representative for China (1988-1990) and Regional Director for Asia Programs (1990-1996). Most of the material consists of newspaper clippings, journal articles, reports, and conference papers, amongst an array of other types of publications and press. These records discuss such topics as economic and political reforms in China, China’s international relations and foreign policy (mostly focused on U.S.-China relations), environmental issues and sustainable development, agricultural development, legal system reform, pro-democracy movements, and government repression of intellectuals and political dissidents. Media coverage and academic analysis of the student-led protests at Tiananmen Square and the June Fourth Incident are featured prominently within the subseries as are the coverage and analysis of the international response to the events and China’s subsequent economic and political trajectory. A few pieces of correspondence from Geithner help to relay his perspective on the incidents. He wrote the letters in May 1989 to family members as well as to the Ford Office in Dhaka, Bangladesh, just days before the violence occurred.   Although the subseries does not include many documents that reveal the Ford Foundation’s specific program activities in China during the times that Geithner was China Representative or Regional Director for Asia Programs, Geithner’s accumulation of these articles and reports suggests that he used these sources to inform his outlook on numerous issues affecting China as well as his program decisions for Ford’s activities in the country. There are notes that indicate he requested the material as well as notes that show he received it from colleagues and personal relations who believed that he would be interested in the content. Moreover, Geithner added notes and annotations to many of the papers and articles. A significant portion of the reports are actually drafts that authors submitted to Geithner for his review.

Title: Henry Kissinger Articles
Ancestor: America-China Society / America-China Forum Programs and Staff (series)
Ancestor Notes: The America-China Society (ACS) was founded in 1987 by Henry Kissinger and Cyrus Vance with the goal of promoting understanding and cooperation between the People’s Republic of China and the United States. Kissinger and Vance co-chaired the organization, which consisted of 35-40 Directors – business executives or former government leaders – who shared interest in China. According to its statement of purpose, “the America-China Society works to increase understanding between the United States and the PRC; to advance diplomatic, commercial, cultural, social, scientific and educational ties; to foster public policies which promote their shared interests; to enhance opportunities for United States enterprises to engage in mutually beneficial investment and trade with the PRC; and to cooperate with governmental and private organizations having comparable objectives.” In January 2000, the ACS directors voted to merge with the National Committee, becoming (around 2001), the America-China Forum of the National Committee on U. S. – China Relations.   The ACS/ACF records in this series consist of Executive Directors correspondence, 1988 – 1999; Directors correspondence, late 1980s – 1990s, and correspondence with Individuals, mid- to late 1990s; organizational records and meeting minutes and materials, 1986 – 2000; records of ACS programs and events; ACS Trip files; and various office files. While some of the meeting, trip, and event files include remarks or notes by Kissinger, materials in the correspondence files pertaining to Kissinger consist mainly of informational memos to him (with marginal responses) or prepared letters.
Parent Collection: National Committee on United States-China Relations records

Title: Emeric - Emmerich
Component Notes: General correspondence and memoranda concerning loans of NAR artworks, possible purchases and inquiries and comments from the public.  Emeric Emig, A. Peter Emmerich, Andre (Andre Emmerich Gallery)
Ancestor Notes: This is an alphabetically arranged subject file maintained by Carol Kinzel Uht (CKU). It documents broad issues concerning the management of the collection that are not necessarily associated with one particular piece of art. It includes correspondence with galleries, auction houses, dealers, and museums regarding art work being lent, bought, or sold. There is also internal correspondence regarding the placement and maintenance of works of art owned by other members of the Rockefeller family.  Included in this subseries are files on art works belonging to Mr. Rockefeller that were damaged or destroyed in the March 1961 fire at the Executive mansion in Albany (filed under "Albany"). His support of the Museum of Modern Art and the Museum of Primitive Art is also evident here. There are also files on the exhibition of portions of his collection at MoMA in 1969.

Title: Society for Japanese Studies - Dilts, Marion M.
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. Title: Public Opinion Polls
Component Notes: Political Situation in New York State, February 1960; voters in California, Illinois, New York, Pennsylvania & Texas, July 1960; New York State Political Surveys, October 1960.
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains a selection of polls and public opinion surveys conducted primarily in New York State, although a small selection concerns national issues. In most cases the polls were conducted by Political Analysis Associates of Princeton, New Jersey. Primarily, the surveys focus on Governor Rockefeller or are specific to an issue within New York State. However, some were undertaken in response to New York City issues, such as two surveys conducted in 1970 on the status of the New York City subway system and a phone survey of New York City Mayor John Lindsay's popularity. In some cases, accompanying memoranda may be found that analyze the poll data for the Governor. Note that this subseries is an incomplete aggregate of the polls conducted in New York State.

Title: Philanthropic contribution summaries
Ancestor Access Restriction: Open for scholarly research, except where specific restrictions are noted.  Material in the Rockefeller family collections that details correspondence with or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family member, is restricted from scholarly access. Additionally, some records are restricted to safeguard personal privacy.
Ancestor Notes: The general Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) files document the broad range of the Rockefeller family’s business and philanthropic interests during the period 1899 to 1961, particularly the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr., in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons—John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David—into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office. These files are grouped by subject-area series, and records covering activities in a particular area of interest are found within the subject series. Therefore, it may prove useful to consult the general OMR files as well as those in the David Rockefeller papers. For example, further details of David Rockefeller’s involvement in the activities of the Museum of Modern Art are in the Cultural Interests series, available here: <extref href="../FA314/overview">FA314 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests</extref>. Similarly, additional information on the Council on Foreign Relations is in the World Affairs series–Foreign Policy section, available here: <extref href="../FA326/overview">FA326 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, World Affairs</extref>. Other available finding aids describing the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records include:  <extref href="../FA310/overview">FA310 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, John D. Rockefeller, Sr.</extref>  <extref href="../FA312/overview">FA312 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Business Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA313/overview">FA313 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Civic Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA314/overview">FA314 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA315/overview">FA315 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Economic Reform Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA316/overview">FA316 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Educational Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA317/overview">FA317 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Friends and Services</extref>  <extref href="../FA318/overview">FA318 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Homes</extref>  <extref href="../FA319/overview">FA319 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Housing Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA320/overview">FA320 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Medical Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA321/overview">FA321 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Real Estate</extref>  <extref href="../FA323/overview">FA323 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Religious Interests</extref>  <extref href="../FA325/overview">FA325 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare - General Files</extref>  <extref href="../FA326/overview">FA326 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, World Affairs</extref>  <extref href="../FA327/overview">FA327 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Welfare - Youth Files</extref>  <extref href="../FA329/overview">FA329 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Public Relations</extref>  <extref href="../FA335/overview">FA335 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal</extref>  <extref href="../FA336/overview">FA336 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller</extref>  <extref href="../FA337/overview">FA337 Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Abby Rockefeller Mauze </extref> | Record Group 2 of the David Rockefeller Papers contains his personal files dated 1918 to 1961 from the Rockefeller family office, known as the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR). The office was located in Rockefeller Center on the 56th floor of the main building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, contemporaneously referred to as the RCA Building.   Mr. Rockefeller’s personal files begin with his formative years and education, documenting his early interest in science and his family’s extensive travels. But the focus of this record group is the 15 years following his service during World War II in the U.S. Army, when David Rockefeller was establishing himself in the arenas of banking, international business, and philanthropy. While his personal and philanthropic activities are well represented in the files, the business records of his 35-year career with Chase Bank are not part of this collection.  The largest portion of this record group comprises 21 boxes of personal correspondence that date from the immediate post-war period until 1961. Mostly unsolicited, these letters come from friends and acquaintances from across the globe and amply illustrate the vast range of relationships he cultivated through the years. Mr. Rockefeller often heard from individuals he met during his wartime service in France and Algiers—which was, in his own words, “the beginning of a networking process that I would follow throughout my life.”* Correspondents of note include Alfred Barr, Jr., Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, Allen and John Foster Dulles, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Dag Hammarskjold, General George C. Marshall, Robert Moses, Arthur Sulzberger, and William Zorach.  Personal correspondence with his parents, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, dates from 1925 until his graduation from Harvard University in 1936, and later with solely his father following Abby’s death in 1948. While there are a handful of files related to David Rockefeller’s wedding to Margaret McGrath and their honeymoon in Wyoming, there is no correspondence between the two prior to their marriage in 1940. Likewise, there is little to no correspondence with his sister and four brothers. Correspondence regarding his children remains closed to research during their respective lifetimes.  Among topics of note in this record group is David Rockefeller’s close association with Harvard University that spans several decades. This includes folders on his financial support of the institution, as well as his lengthy service on its Board of Overseers. Additionally, folders on his 25th class reunion in 1961—for which he was elected Chief Marshall of the event—are complemented by details of his efforts to mount a special art exhibition for the occasion. Other aspects of his lifelong love of art are evident in the folders on the Museum of Modern Art, which his mother co-founded and on whose board Mr. Rockefeller served starting in 1948. Furthermore, information on the origins of his own art collecting is found in Folders 210-217.  From a young age, David Rockefeller fully embraced his family’s tradition of extensive travel. His 1932 handwritten accounts of a biking trip in England before starting college detailed the summer adventure in letters home to his parents (Folder 437). In 1935, he toured dozens of European art museums with close friend Richard Gilder, his Harvard roommate who later died while serving as a combat pilot in World War II. During that trip, Richard wrote a particularly poignant letter to Abby Rockefeller that describes their summer travels through Europe and focuses on the ominous developments in Germany as the continent headed toward war (Folder 441).  Lastly, this record group includes personal and quasi-professional files from 1959 to 1981 that the Chase Manhattan Bank transferred to the family office following David Rockefeller’s retirement in 1981. These are mostly chronological, event-specific folders.  * Rockefeller, David, Memoirs, New York: Random House, 2002, page 122.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Harvard University - Kelsen, Hans - (Refugee Scholar, Political Science)
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Correspondence with former students and fellow scientists often includes tidbits regarding experiments or projects as well as shared findings. Subject matter ranges from atomic bombs to animal pathology and psychological abilities to employment recommendations for former students and colleagues. A few candid photographs and machine print outs were attached to correspondence and have been left with the correspondence rather than separating such a small number of items and possibly losing valuable context.

Title: Massachusetts Department of Mental Diseases
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Atlantic Studies
Ancestor Notes: In late 1970 the officers of the Rockefeller Foundation allocated $300,000 to launch a program of grants to individuals engaged in the study of America's "cultural heritage." The following year, they appropriated an additional $500,000 to support similar initiatives on an institutional level.  Taking shape in a time of political, social, and cultural ferment, the American Cultural Heritage Program broadly aspired to "provide an alternative" to the "cynicism" and "self-doubt" that seemed to characterize Americans' understanding of their nation and their past. The alternative the officers envisioned was no simple-minded recitation of American myths, but rather a careful and creative reexamination of America's heritage "in the light of present problems." Greater self-understanding would lead to greater "awareness among Americans of their historical and cultural interdependence," a necessary first step to surmounting the problems that divided them. Such a critical reappraisal would also be a worthy contribution to the approaching national bicentennial commemoration.  The Cultural Heritage Program sought out promising younger scholars in the humanities and social sciences and particularly valued creative and interdisciplinary approaches. "Intellectual excellence, broad social commitment, and an imaginative approach" were the criteria that would guide institutional grants. With both the individual and institutional grants, the Foundation's goal was to "make an important contribution to the self-understanding of America's populace," and then to help shape the future by disseminating these new views of the past through formal and informal educational programs.  The projects funded vary widely but are notable for the impetus they display to seek out new questions and new ways of answering them. The question of "identities" and the contributions of minorities to the American nation were primary areas of study. Grantees studied transitions in Alaskan Eskimo life, Emancipation Day celebrations, Chinese workers in Oregon, recent immigrant communities, the role of black religion, and the works of black and women writers. The grants favored projects that sought to apply new disciplines and new techniques to the consideration of American culture. Through oral histories and field research, historians and others used the tools of anthropology to understand their own society. Oral history projects documented labor unrest in the Midwest, southern politicians, and American music, among other topics. On an institutional level, American Cultural Heritage grants launched major centers for the study of Atlantic, Southern, and Appalachian history.  Film, television production, and photographic studies make up another segment of these grants. Projects funded include photographic studies of the American farm, of four Texas counties, of grassroots Christianity, and of blacks in America. Films on folk traditions and television productions on the history of a New England mill town and on the social history of technology in America also received support. The University of Iowa received funding for a program to integrate the study of film and American civilization.  While some projects, like the Atlantic Studies Center at Johns Hopkins University, received major funding and some grants went to well-established scholars and institutions, the foundation's concern to cast its grants widely is striking. In assessing a grant to collect a history of the Gros Ventre tribe, for example, the foundation officer noted that while they could look for someone with "fancier credentials," they might also give "direct and substantial encouragement" to this "diligent amateur." The foundation also was concerned, in redressing the historical record, that the story be told by those who had lived it. The focus on oral history reflects this interest, but the concern was really a broader one to empower minorities to interpret their own heritage. Officers carefully considered a scholar's rapport with the community under study and gave extra weight to a shared regional or ethnic background. They favored one proposal, for example, because it presented the "possibility of furthering Southern Studies by people from this region, in this region." Some grants trained individuals in techniques that could then be brought back to the community.  The smallest grant - for $615 - allowed a scholar to complete a study of the black poet and novelist Jean Toomer. As the final grant report noted, people were impressed that "of all the RF's worldwide activities, . . . we could still take time to make such a small grant for such an obscure project."  While the American Cultural Heritage Program was a limited initiative, it is interesting to see the ways it intersected with and helped shape new initiatives in historical study. It encouraged interdisciplinary and particularly anthropological approaches to historical questions, supported the study of folklore, family history, religion, labor history, women's studies, community and regional studies, and embraced the application of new media to the presentation of traditional subjects. That these approaches are commonplace in textbooks today attests in some measure to the program's success. Researchers may also find in these files reflections of present-day concerns with cultural identity, heritage, and meaning.

Title: Ascroft, Peter B. - (Visit, Neurosurgery) - Report
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Title: Shio Sakanishi
Ancestor Notes: Letters in this series are separate from correspondence found in Series 2 which is affiliated with a specific job or employer.  Letters were received from a wide range of people, including strangers, acquaintances, and friends and professional colleagues from all stages of Burton’s life.  Numerous Rockefeller Foundation colleagues, U.S. diplomats, and Asian scholars and politicians corresponded with Burton.  Letters can be quite brief and perfunctory, or they can be lengthy and full of warmth and collegiality.    Correspondence dating after 1980 was received by Jamie Ross Fahs, who incorporated her letters into her husband’s files.  Generally these letters include information about Burton’s relationship with the correspondent.  Important correspondents in this series include:  John Kenneth Emmerson, Naomi Fukuda, Clifton Forster, Richard H. Minear, Virginia Moreno, Shigeharu Matsumoto, John E. Reinhardt, Edwin O. Reischauer, Flora Rhind, Dean Rusk, Shio Sakanishi, Margaret Shedd, and David H. Stevens.

Title: American Library Association - Microphotography
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Correspondence (1 of 2)
Ancestor Notes: <emph render="bold">Series I. Ford Foundation Refugee Fund, 1952-1957</emph>   This series, arranged alphabetically, consists of Treasurer’s Department files relating to the administration of the Ford Foundation Refugee Fund. The files contain correspondence and memoranda between the Ford Foundation Treasurer’s Department and Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to whom the Foundation entrusted the administration of the fund. The documents detail financial and logistical matters such as the administration of grants (1952), establishing procedures for recording cancellation of appropriations (1952), and policy for the purchase and issuing of grant payments in blocked schillings (1952-1957). Also included are monthly financial reports prepared by the United Nations High Commissioner detailing the progress made in administering funds.

Ancestor Notes: The General Education Board (GEB) was established in 1903 by John D. Rockefeller to aid education in the U.S. "without distinction of race, sex or creed." The program included grants for endowment and general budgetary support of colleges and universities, support for special programs, fellowship and scholarship assistance to state school systems at all levels, and development of social and economic resources as a route to improved educational systems. Major colleges and universities across the U.S., as well as many small institutions in every state, received aid from the Board. The emphasis, however, was on the South and the education of Blacks. Offices were established in Richmond, Virginia, and Baton Rouge, Louisiana, to give GEB agents closer contact with southern communities. The Board was especially active in promoting the public school movement in the early part of the twentieth century. After 1940, programs other than those for southern education were brought to a close; funds were nearly exhausted by the 1950s, and the last appropriation was made in 1964.

Title: Bradley Home (Equipment)
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Atlantic Studies
Ancestor Notes: In late 1970 the officers of the Rockefeller Foundation allocated $300,000 to launch a program of grants to individuals engaged in the study of America's "cultural heritage." The following year, they appropriated an additional $500,000 to support similar initiatives on an institutional level.  Taking shape in a time of political, social, and cultural ferment, the American Cultural Heritage Program broadly aspired to "provide an alternative" to the "cynicism" and "self-doubt" that seemed to characterize Americans' understanding of their nation and their past. The alternative the officers envisioned was no simple-minded recitation of American myths, but rather a careful and creative reexamination of America's heritage "in the light of present problems." Greater self-understanding would lead to greater "awareness among Americans of their historical and cultural interdependence," a necessary first step to surmounting the problems that divided them. Such a critical reappraisal would also be a worthy contribution to the approaching national bicentennial commemoration.  The Cultural Heritage Program sought out promising younger scholars in the humanities and social sciences and particularly valued creative and interdisciplinary approaches. "Intellectual excellence, broad social commitment, and an imaginative approach" were the criteria that would guide institutional grants. With both the individual and institutional grants, the Foundation's goal was to "make an important contribution to the self-understanding of America's populace," and then to help shape the future by disseminating these new views of the past through formal and informal educational programs.  The projects funded vary widely but are notable for the impetus they display to seek out new questions and new ways of answering them. The question of "identities" and the contributions of minorities to the American nation were primary areas of study. Grantees studied transitions in Alaskan Eskimo life, Emancipation Day celebrations, Chinese workers in Oregon, recent immigrant communities, the role of black religion, and the works of black and women writers. The grants favored projects that sought to apply new disciplines and new techniques to the consideration of American culture. Through oral histories and field research, historians and others used the tools of anthropology to understand their own society. Oral history projects documented labor unrest in the Midwest, southern politicians, and American music, among other topics. On an institutional level, American Cultural Heritage grants launched major centers for the study of Atlantic, Southern, and Appalachian history.  Film, television production, and photographic studies make up another segment of these grants. Projects funded include photographic studies of the American farm, of four Texas counties, of grassroots Christianity, and of blacks in America. Films on folk traditions and television productions on the history of a New England mill town and on the social history of technology in America also received support. The University of Iowa received funding for a program to integrate the study of film and American civilization.  While some projects, like the Atlantic Studies Center at Johns Hopkins University, received major funding and some grants went to well-established scholars and institutions, the foundation's concern to cast its grants widely is striking. In assessing a grant to collect a history of the Gros Ventre tribe, for example, the foundation officer noted that while they could look for someone with "fancier credentials," they might also give "direct and substantial encouragement" to this "diligent amateur." The foundation also was concerned, in redressing the historical record, that the story be told by those who had lived it. The focus on oral history reflects this interest, but the concern was really a broader one to empower minorities to interpret their own heritage. Officers carefully considered a scholar's rapport with the community under study and gave extra weight to a shared regional or ethnic background. They favored one proposal, for example, because it presented the "possibility of furthering Southern Studies by people from this region, in this region." Some grants trained individuals in techniques that could then be brought back to the community.  The smallest grant - for $615 - allowed a scholar to complete a study of the black poet and novelist Jean Toomer. As the final grant report noted, people were impressed that "of all the RF's worldwide activities, . . . we could still take time to make such a small grant for such an obscure project."  While the American Cultural Heritage Program was a limited initiative, it is interesting to see the ways it intersected with and helped shape new initiatives in historical study. It encouraged interdisciplinary and particularly anthropological approaches to historical questions, supported the study of folklore, family history, religion, labor history, women's studies, community and regional studies, and embraced the application of new media to the presentation of traditional subjects. That these approaches are commonplace in textbooks today attests in some measure to the program's success. Researchers may also find in these files reflections of present-day concerns with cultural identity, heritage, and meaning.

Title: Impressions of China
Component Notes: Institution: Brown University Occasion: Brown University dinner Subject: Education Format: Handwritten
Ancestor: John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Personal Papers - Speeches (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. became well known for his Bible class lessons. Speeches demonstrate his theological classes first took place (1894) at the YMCA when JDR Jr. was a student at Brown University. After graduation from Brown, JDR Jr. became affiliated with his father at 26 Broadway, New York City. He participated actively as a member of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, and there, for a period of 10 years, conducted a Young Man's Bible Class. A number of these Bible class lessons are included in the speech file. A majority of the speeches he delivered throughout his life echo the religious themes he developed during his years as a Bible class teacher.  JDR Jr. gradually eased out of much of the family business and turned his attention and dedication to philanthropic endeavors. The speech file richly reveals the causes JDR Jr. espoused. His keen interest in the arts prompted such undertakings as the erection of The Cloisters and Rockefeller Center. Rockefeller contributions, under the direction of JDR Jr., formed the basis for the restoration projects of Williamsburg, Virginia, and several historic properties in Westchester County, New York. JDR Jr.'s interest in historical preservation extended beyond the United States. He became deeply involved in the restoration projects of the Palace of Versailles, Fontainebleau, and the cathedral of Rheims.  JDR Jr. was a key supporter, during both world wars, of service organizations that would benefit and build morale among the United States servicemen. A number of speeches reflect this interest.  As chairman of the General Education Board and the International Education Board, education was a prime source of interest to JDR Jr. He sought the betterment of men and women through education both in the United States and abroad. Most prominent in the speech subseries is JDR Jr.'s work on behalf of the United Negro College Fund Campaign and the establishment of the Peking Union Medical College.  John D. Rockefeller, Jr. firmly believed in promoting greater understanding between labor and capital. He, with the able guidance of Mackenzie King, sought to establish workable partnerships between labor and capital. The speech file contains many of the speeches he delivered on this subject.  Each speech is assigned to one of the following 10 subject areas: Brotherhood, Education, Fund, Labor, Personal, Religion, Restoration, Social Welfare, Stewardship, Tribute.  Subject areas were assigned by the General Files staff and the processing archivist.  Other information in each entry includes: Title (assigned by John D. Rockefeller, Jr.), Institution (or group to whom the speech was given), Occasion (reason for the speech), Place (geographic location), Format (includes handwritten outline, typed, magazine article, printed pamphlet).

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biological Research
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Handicrafts Survey
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: ALA 160.2 - Alabama Homemakers Clubs
Component Notes: Students, Schools, Clubs
Ancestor Access Restriction: Photographs, slides, and other images are open for scholarly research.  RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.
Ancestor Notes: The General Education Board (GEB) was established in 1903 by John D. Rockefeller to aid education in the U.S. "without distinction of race, sex or creed." The program included grants for endowment and general budgetary support of colleges and universities, support for special programs, fellowship and scholarship assistance to state school systems at all levels, and development of social and economic resources as a route to improved educational systems. Major colleges and universities across the U.S., as well as many small institutions in every state, received aid from the Board. The emphasis, however, was on the South and the education of Blacks. Offices were established in Richmond, Virginia, and Baton Rouge, Louisiana, to give GEB agents closer contact with southern communities. The Board was especially active in promoting the public school movement in the early part of the twentieth century. After 1940, programs other than those for southern education were brought to a close; funds were nearly exhausted by the 1950s, and the last appropriation was made in 1964.

Title: Program and Policy - Agriculture
Ancestor Notes: Correspondence, memoranda and reports concerning the development and administration of programs in agriculture and in natural sciences. The agricultural interests were combined with the Natural Sciences Division in 1946. A new program called Natural Sciences and Agriculture was formed in 1951. The natural sciences aspect was terminated in 1955. It was resurrected in 1959 when two new programs were formed: Agricultural Sciences; and Medical and Natural Sciences.   | SEE ALSO: Series 900 General Program and Policy, Program and Policy, Food SEE ALSO: Series 923 Agriculture SEE ALSO: Series 924 Medical and Natural Sciences

Title: Massachusetts Department of Mental Diseases - Reprints
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: University of Cambridge - Economics
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.   After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.   Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: New York Public Library - Microfilm
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Harvard University - Kelsen, Hans - (Refugee Scholar, Political Science)
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Nursing Education, Negro - Survey
Ancestor Notes: In this small subseries most of the material originated between the years 1918 and 1935. The files contain information relating to the development of public health nursing and to education for nurses in the eastern United States. Uniformity of standards in nurses training was the Foundation's main concern. At first the Foundation's program in nursing was administered by Edwin Embree as part of the program of the Division of Studies. After the reorganization of 1927-1938, nursing was transferred, first to the province of Richard M. Pearce and the Division of Medical Education, later to the International Health Division.   Personnel in nursing in the Rockefeller Foundation included F. Elizabeth Crowell, who worked mostly in the field, and Mary Beard, former president of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing, who worked in the United States from 1925 to 1938. There is much of her correspondence in these files. | For information about projects in nursing in other countries see the appropriate country number. Nursing Fellowship files are in Record Group 10, Fellowships. In the files of the Paris Office, Record Group 6 Field Offices, Subgroup 1, there are fellowship and general correspondence files pertaining to nursing.
