Title: Christianity in Business
Component Notes: Institution: Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) Place: Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island Subject: Religion Format: Handwritten/Typed
Ancestor: John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Personal Papers - Speeches (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. became well known for his Bible class lessons. Speeches demonstrate his theological classes first took place (1894) at the YMCA when JDR Jr. was a student at Brown University. After graduation from Brown, JDR Jr. became affiliated with his father at 26 Broadway, New York City. He participated actively as a member of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, and there, for a period of 10 years, conducted a Young Man's Bible Class. A number of these Bible class lessons are included in the speech file. A majority of the speeches he delivered throughout his life echo the religious themes he developed during his years as a Bible class teacher.  JDR Jr. gradually eased out of much of the family business and turned his attention and dedication to philanthropic endeavors. The speech file richly reveals the causes JDR Jr. espoused. His keen interest in the arts prompted such undertakings as the erection of The Cloisters and Rockefeller Center. Rockefeller contributions, under the direction of JDR Jr., formed the basis for the restoration projects of Williamsburg, Virginia, and several historic properties in Westchester County, New York. JDR Jr.'s interest in historical preservation extended beyond the United States. He became deeply involved in the restoration projects of the Palace of Versailles, Fontainebleau, and the cathedral of Rheims.  JDR Jr. was a key supporter, during both world wars, of service organizations that would benefit and build morale among the United States servicemen. A number of speeches reflect this interest.  As chairman of the General Education Board and the International Education Board, education was a prime source of interest to JDR Jr. He sought the betterment of men and women through education both in the United States and abroad. Most prominent in the speech subseries is JDR Jr.'s work on behalf of the United Negro College Fund Campaign and the establishment of the Peking Union Medical College.  John D. Rockefeller, Jr. firmly believed in promoting greater understanding between labor and capital. He, with the able guidance of Mackenzie King, sought to establish workable partnerships between labor and capital. The speech file contains many of the speeches he delivered on this subject.  Each speech is assigned to one of the following 10 subject areas: Brotherhood, Education, Fund, Labor, Personal, Religion, Restoration, Social Welfare, Stewardship, Tribute.  Subject areas were assigned by the General Files staff and the processing archivist.  Other information in each entry includes: Title (assigned by John D. Rockefeller, Jr.), Institution (or group to whom the speech was given), Occasion (reason for the speech), Place (geographic location), Format (includes handwritten outline, typed, magazine article, printed pamphlet).

Title: 1. Memoranda and Reports
Ancestor Notes: Material, mostly 1913-1942, relating to projects originated by international organizations or involving more than one country. Included in this designation are organizations directly connected with the Rockefeller Foundation, such as the International Health Division (which was a part of the Foundation governed separately until 1951); organizations indirectly related to the Foundation, such as the Spelman Fund of New York and the China Medical Board, Inc.; and other, independent organizations which received support from the Foundation. Much of the material concerns the work of the International Health Division. There is a large section on the war relief of the Foundation (1914-1918). Additional items of interest are a progress report on nursing education (1928), an anthropological survey (1932-1933), and the files on international studies and international relations. | For information concerning specific countries consult the appropriate country series. Correspondence and reports relating to international affairs can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2. Record Group 5, International Health Board/Division, contains correspondence and reports prior to 1928, and reports from 1928 to 1958. International Health Division material can also be found in Record Group 3, Administration, Program and Policy, Series 908, and in Record Group 6, Field Offices, Subgroup 1, Paris. | For preservation reasons, an embroidered flour sack was removed from an unknown location within this collection, and rehoused. It was a real cotton flour sack, with drawings and embroidery to commemorate the RF's war relief work in Belgium. It has been relocated in the flat files in Vault 107, see Oversize Inventory for specifics.

Title: Harvard University - Epilepsy
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Handicrafts Survey - Report - "Teacher Training in Handicrafts" - by Robert S. Whitelaw
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Program and Policy - Reports Pro-al "Report on Visit to China," - by Selskar M. Gunn
Ancestor Notes: From 1913 to 1928 the Foundation's interests in China were directed by the China Medical Board, a division of the foundation. In 1928 the China Medical Board was separately incorporated and the functions continued by the Foundation were transferred to the Foundation's Division of Medical Education. Series 601 contains material after 1928, except for the Historical Records, which go back to 1913. Although the bulk of the material originated before 1945, there is also correspondence as late as 1960. The material consists of correspondence, memos, and reports relating to specific grants, and reports of a general nature which are filed in the 601 (General) section. A section on program and policy contains administrative and policy information in various forms.   Major areas of interest were agriculture and rural economics, public health and medicine. Grants were made predominantly to hospitals, universities and institutes of research. Of special interest are the files on rural reconstruction, the Mass Education movement, and the Peking Union Medical College. | For a more complete view of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China the records of the China Medical Board, Record Group 4 and of the China Medical Board, Inc. Collection should be consulted. Correspondence and reports can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2.   See also - 6.1 Field Office-Paris.

Title: 4. Correspondence
Ancestor Notes: Material, mostly 1913-1942, relating to projects originated by international organizations or involving more than one country. Included in this designation are organizations directly connected with the Rockefeller Foundation, such as the International Health Division (which was a part of the Foundation governed separately until 1951); organizations indirectly related to the Foundation, such as the Spelman Fund of New York and the China Medical Board, Inc.; and other, independent organizations which received support from the Foundation. Much of the material concerns the work of the International Health Division. There is a large section on the war relief of the Foundation (1914-1918). Additional items of interest are a progress report on nursing education (1928), an anthropological survey (1932-1933), and the files on international studies and international relations. | For information concerning specific countries consult the appropriate country series. Correspondence and reports relating to international affairs can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2. Record Group 5, International Health Board/Division, contains correspondence and reports prior to 1928, and reports from 1928 to 1958. International Health Division material can also be found in Record Group 3, Administration, Program and Policy, Series 908, and in Record Group 6, Field Offices, Subgroup 1, Paris. | For preservation reasons, an embroidered flour sack was removed from an unknown location within this collection, and rehoused. It was a real cotton flour sack, with drawings and embroidery to commemorate the RF's war relief work in Belgium. It has been relocated in the flat files in Vault 107, see Oversize Inventory for specifics.

Title: Library of Congress - Microphotography
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's earliest program in the humanities was inherited from the International Education Board and the General Education Board. Edward Capps, director in 1929-1930, administered a program concentrating on teaching and research in classical studies, emphasizing fluid research funds. For two years humanities was without a director until David H. Stevens was appointed in 1932. Subsequently a new program was developed emphasizing improved world communication through national libraries and teaching of essential languages. In early years 1932-1939, this program was concentrated on four main geographical areas - the Far East, Latin America, the Slavic region and the United States. Support was also given to early experiments in microfilm and radio research.   During the war years, 1939-1945, early experience in mass communication proved valuable, and support was given for work in microfilm, especially for preservation of endangered records, for radio listening centers and propaganda analysis, and public opinion polling. Language training continued to be important. European humanists were aided in their efforts to reach this country and resume productive lives.   After 1945, although support for Far East and Slavic studies continued, there was a new emphasis on America in the Foundation's program, seen in grants for regional studies and grants in aid of American scholarly publishing.   Humanities in creative aspects had support chiefly in the advance of community and university drama. A substantial grant was made to start the Berkshire Music Center.   Mostly material from the 1930's - 1950's. David H. Stevens remained director of the humanities program until 1950. There was no foundation in the arts at this time.

Title: Rural Reconstruction
Ancestor Notes: From 1913 to 1928 the Foundation's interests in China were directed by the China Medical Board, a division of the foundation. In 1928 the China Medical Board was separately incorporated and the functions continued by the Foundation were transferred to the Foundation's Division of Medical Education. Series 601 contains material after 1928, except for the Historical Records, which go back to 1913. Although the bulk of the material originated before 1945, there is also correspondence as late as 1960. The material consists of correspondence, memos, and reports relating to specific grants, and reports of a general nature which are filed in the 601 (General) section. A section on program and policy contains administrative and policy information in various forms.   Major areas of interest were agriculture and rural economics, public health and medicine. Grants were made predominantly to hospitals, universities and institutes of research. Of special interest are the files on rural reconstruction, the Mass Education movement, and the Peking Union Medical College. | For a more complete view of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China the records of the China Medical Board, Record Group 4 and of the China Medical Board, Inc. Collection should be consulted. Correspondence and reports can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2.   See also - 6.1 Field Office-Paris.

Title: Japan - Dulles (John F.), Report for
Ancestor Notes: Through correspondence, reports, and memoranda, this subseries documents Rockefeller's interest in and commitment to Asia. Rockefeller was deeply concerned about the need for increasing America's understanding and appreciation of the peoples of Asia. To that end, he was involved in the support of cultural exchange programs; the revival of the Japan Society; the formation of the Asia Society; the construction of Asia House, the Asia Society's New York City headquarters; and the construction of the International House of Japan in Tokyo. The files documenting the teaching of the English language in Japan (folders 452-455) reflect Rockefeller's belief in the importance of English to Japan's growth in the international community. Also included here are files relating to the Council on Economic and Cultural Affairs, Inc. (CECA), an organization established by Rockefeller in 1953 to stimulate and support economic and related activities focusing on Asia. Rockefeller's work for the John Foster Dulles peace mission to Japan in 1951 led to a renewed acquaintance with Shigeharu Matsumoto, with whom he had worked at the Institute of Pacific Relations conference in 1929. The Matsumoto and Rockefeller families became close friends. Included in this subseries are Rockefeller's report for Dulles and the State Department (folder 446), as well as correspondence between Matsumoto and JDR 3rd (folders 477-478). Also represented here are two commercial ventures developed by Rockefeller to sell in the United States quality merchandise manufactured in Asia, namely, Products of Asia, Inc. and Products of India, Inc. These companies, which were meant to increase trade and encourage cultural contact, were sold in 1965. | For additional Matsumoto family correspondence see series 3, subseries 2, folder 147.

Title: Public Opinion Polls
Component Notes: New York Survey, May 1959; Six States Survey, October 1959; Oregon Issues, November 1959; Campaign Strategy, December 1959.
Ancestor Notes: This subseries contains a selection of polls and public opinion surveys conducted primarily in New York State, although a small selection concerns national issues. In most cases the polls were conducted by Political Analysis Associates of Princeton, New Jersey. Primarily, the surveys focus on Governor Rockefeller or are specific to an issue within New York State. However, some were undertaken in response to New York City issues, such as two surveys conducted in 1970 on the status of the New York City subway system and a phone survey of New York City Mayor John Lindsay's popularity. In some cases, accompanying memoranda may be found that analyze the poll data for the Governor. Note that this subseries is an incomplete aggregate of the polls conducted in New York State.

Title: Cornell University - Civil Liberties
Ancestor Notes: The Rockefeller Foundation took over from the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial a well developed program in the social sciences. This program had emphasized the promotion of fundamental and applied social sciences and research in the areas of social disturbance and problems of socially maladjusted groups.   In 1933, the Trustees of the Foundation called for a program in human relations complementary to the medical science program in psychiatry and the natural sciences program in human biology. A program was developed which included international relations, economic stabilization, social security, the public administration. Special objectives of this program were the training of technical and administrative personnel and liaison between practitioner and research groups in these fields. Grants were made to organizations such as the Foreign Policy Association, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Institute of Pacific Relations and the Brookings Institution. Projects at leading universities were aided.   Other fields in which the Foundation had an interest include housing, cultural anthropology, and criminology. These were never developed fully. There was always a strong interest in strengthening the social science field, especially through such organizations as the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the Social Science Research Council. Most of the files in this section are from the 30's and 40's.   Directors of the social science program were Edmund E. Day (1929-1937), Sydnor H. Walker, Acting (1937-1938), and Joseph H. Willits (1939-1954).

Title: Outgoing Correspondence - Santayana, George
Ancestor Notes: Series 2, Professional Correspondence, fills Boxes 4 through 8 and contains Strong's correspondence with philosophers and writers. Strong's correspondents include Bernard and Mary Berenson, Henri Bergson, Alfred Binet, John Dewey, G. Lowes Dickinson, John Galsworthy, William James, Arthur O. Lovejoy, John Masefield, G. E. Moore, Friedrich Paulsen (1 letter), Charles S. Peirce (2 letters), Ralph Barton Perry (2 letters), Walter Rauschenbusch, Bertrand Russell, George Santayana, F. C. S. Schiller, and Paul Shorey. Among his most faithful colleagues and critics were Durant Drake (Vassar College), Dickinson S. Miller (Columbia), James Bissett Pratt (Williams College), A. K. Rogers (Yale) and Roy Wood Sellars (University of Michigan). Strong's outgoing correspondence includes a packet entitled "My Letters to Philosophers" (1902-12).  George Santayana's correspondence with Strong, located in Series 2, is the largest single correspondence in the collection. The letters are uninterrupted for the period 1900 to 1939 and fill twenty folders. Most of the letters were written after 1912 during extended sojourns in France, Italy, Germany, and Spain. Santayana's letters are warm and full of personal anecdote, and report on the books he is reading as well as the progress of his own writings, including "The Realm of Matter" (1930), "The Realm of Truth" (1937), "The Realm of Spirit" (1940), and the novel, "The Last Puritan" (1939). Although they remained loyal friends, Strong and Santayana continually disagreed over the scope and limits of perception. Their philosophical differences gradually took on a personal edge. After a 1938 meeting in Rome, which led to an altercation, Santayana wrote that he and Strong had fallen "out of sympathy on almost every current subject." In 1939, he declared, "Your presuppositions as to what can and what cannot excite consciousness are not such as I feel any need of making." Strong's letters to Santayana fill three folders and consist mainly of transcript drafts of letters for the years 1930, 1932 and 1933 concerning philosophical subjects.  The letters of William James to Charles Strong fill seven folders and are largely uninterrupted for the period 1898 to 1910, the year of James' death. In his letters, James discusses materialism, his reactions to Strong's writings, books he is reading, his teaching load, travel plans, family life, and the precarious state of his health. He describes in 1905 his first encounter with French philosopher Henri Bergson. Writing on 6 February 1906 from Palo Alto, where he was lecturing at Stanford University, he gives a lively account of his reaction to the San Francisco earthquake. Strong's letters to James fill one folder. Two letters (1889), written from Berlin, offer a theory of materialism explaining the relationship between the mind and the body, in which the human mind is a product of natural processes. Strong's theory found formal expression in his first book, "Why the Mind has a Body" (1903).

Title: Johns Hopkins University - Biochemistry - Andrews, Donald - Reports
Ancestor: United States - Natural Sciences and Agriculture (subseries)
Ancestor Notes: The Foundation's program in natural sciences developed from the old programs of the IEB and GEB. Under the direction of Wickliffe Rose, those organizations emphasized mathematics, physics, and chemistry. After a trial period, 1929-1932, during which the natural sciences division had five directors or acting directors, Warren Weaver was appointed director, remaining until 1951. A new program was developed, at first called "vital processes," later "modern experimental biology," to meet the desire of the Trustees for a people-oriented program based on the idea that the natural sciences were essential to medicine. The programs in medical science and natural science were intended to be complementary.   This group of files contains material mostly from the 1930's and 40' relating to research projects in subjects such as biophysics, biochemistry, genetics and physiology. A number of European refugee scholars were aided under this program. The application of physical and chemical techniques to biology, genetics and nutrition was of special interest. There are no files relating to agriculture in this subseries.

Title: Broadcasting grants, historical list of
Ancestor Notes: Correspondence, memoranda, agendas, reports and research materials compiled by Friendly on a variety of topics relating to broadcasting, telecommunications, journalism and law. There are substantial files on the early design and implementation of community antenna television (CATV, or cable television) systems, especially in the New York City region, satellite broadcast technology, and the Foundation-funded operations of public television stations and organizations including National Educational Television (NET) and the Public Broadcast Laboratory. Reports and memos from the Office of Public Broadcasting and Office of Communications (box 19, folders 8-12) illuminate staff thinking during the period when Foundation support for public television was dramatically reduced.

Title: Harvard University - Legal Medicine
Ancestor Notes: Most of the files in this section date from the 1930's and 40's. The Foundation's program in the medical sciences during this period was directed by Dr. Alan Gregg and was concentrated in psychiatry and neurology and related subjects - neuroanatomy, heredity, endocrinology, neuropathology, child guidance, industrial psychology and sex research. Emphasis was placed on worker training, selected research projects and measures to improve or extend the application of existing knowledge. The medical sciences program also devoted part of its resources to the development of university teaching departments of public health. The program was conceived to be complementary to the natural sciences program in human biology. Although it developed out of the old Division of Medical Education of the Foundation, the Medical Sciences division had no program in medical education in the United States, except for a small program of post-war medical fellowship grants to leading universities. | For information about the establishment of medical schools see the files of the General Education Board. Consult also the state inventories.

Title: Aspira Inc.
Ancestor Notes: The Grants series documents the Taconic Foundation's grantmaking from its inception in the late 1950s and early 1960s up to, but generally not including, its final grant cycles and spend-down in 2008-2012. Records concerning these latter grants are found, for the most part, not in the Grants series, but in the Organization Records series, under "Grantmaking and Foundation History" or under "Spend-Down Process." These late grants are grouped collectively rather than by individual grantee.  Grant files contain proposals, correspondence, and reports, and sometimes publications or literature relating to the institution or the particular grant. Most grant files also include one or more grant memos, which Taconic Foundation officers wrote for each new grant or renewal, setting forth for the board the terms of the request, the nature of the organization and its history with Taconic, previous funding, the pros and cons of the proposed grant, its fit with the Taconic program, and the recommended action.  The Taconic Foundation also funded a number of "Projects" that produced research and reports on issues of concern to the foundation or that resulted in the creation of new organizations that then benefited from Taconic grant support. Projects included, for example, the Assessment Project on Negro Needs, Davidoff's and Gold's proposals for low-income housing in lower Manhattan, the Voter Education Project, the Smokey House Project, and the Cooperative Assistance Fund.   A number of simple correspondence files are interspersed in this grants series. Each of these files generally contains just a few pieces of correspondence. While some correspondents have connections to Taconic projects, for the most part the correspondence files seem to be remnants of either a finite correspondence or a larger series. There is no general correspondence series in the Taconic records, and the Grants series constitutes the main series of files.  The Grants series is fairly comprehensive, but it is not a complete set of grant files. Some significant reports, such as Mary Conway Kohler's study of Youth and Work in New York, are not found in the files. Records are sparse or sometimes lacking for some of the Taconic Foundation's early grants. Many of the early programs were first launched with personal grants from the Curriers before the Taconic Foundation assumed their funding, and these hybrid origins may, perhaps, account for some of the gaps.

Title: CHUL-1a Ellis, Aller G. "Siam-Medical Education: A Review of Cooperation Between the RF and the Siamese Government"
Ancestor Notes: The earliest material in this series (1915) is a survey of medical education in Siam, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education. Most of the series consists of grants for visiting professors to Chulanlongkorn University and the development of nursing education at Siriraj Hospital.
